title: The National WWII Museum, New Orleans
review_list:
Don't short change yourself by expecting to conquer this museum in a few hours. It's worthy of much more. They didn't cut any corners when designing the exhibits to ensure a modern interactive learning experience. Plan to spend 4-5 hours and soak it up. You'll be glad you did.

Fantastic immersive experience but too intense for my not easily shaken up 9 year old. I read about this ahead of time and no one else mentioned this. We wound up leaving early. She is a little history buff but it was just too much for her. It makes sense! War is terrifying for all of us. I wouldn't want...


More  



This is an ever-expanding complex/collection that is well-funded, well-designed, and well-stocked with planes (suspended from ceiling, some) and general memorabilia and displays. Very thoughtful staff and it has really evolved over the years. A must-see for any visitor and the special events there are also worth checking. Architecturally stunning.

This facility gives you a glimpse into WWII from an interactive perspective. You can travel through the European theatre, and the newly opened Pacific theatre, accompanied by artifacts from the war.

This was a great last minute visit. Me and my two brother in laws decided we wanted to visit this place and it was really interesting. We paid the full price which included a 4D movie narrated by Tom Hanks and an interactive submarine experience.
The movie was amazing with a lot of special effects, bright lights and set pieces...


More  



Excellent!! A must do!! This was such an experience highly recommend!! Great in helping understand about war!

This is one of the best museums anywhere on the world on any subject matter. It has three or four buildings housing a theater with a 45 minutes long 4 dimensional film (props emerging from the stage's trap doors) narrated by Tom Hanks (like a Disney ride with rumbling seats and fake snow), a large collection of WWII aircraft (sponsored...


More  



I'm sorry, but I really don't have the words to describe this museum. Nevertheless I'm going to try because, if you are into military history or if you value the sacrifice that our veterans have made for this country, then I owe you an attempt.
This was not my first visit to this remarkable place. Each time it is more...


More  



Didn't know this museum existed until a few days before my trip! Went my first day there, and was happy to be able to walk from my French Quarter hotel. Easy to navigate, informative and visually compelling historical displays and a 45 minute movie narrated by Tom Hanks! Rated one of the 5 best museums in the country

If you do nothing else on a visit to New Orleans a visit to the WW II Museum is a must. The two new exhibits - the war in the Pacific and the road to Berlin are fantastic. The information is excellent particularly after you have seen the Tom Hanks movie.

title: Jackson Square, New Orleans
address: 615 Pere Antoine Alley, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
Loved it. So fun to wander and check everything out. Print out a guide to the history, makes it much more fun! Musicians playing and street performers were cool to see also.

Most tourists end up here, but it's still a place to check out. There are some very good street musicians and you definitely want to see Andrew Jackson's equestrian statue by Clark Mills.

This is the historical center of the French Quarter, and is located near many of the tours and attractions in the district. It gives you a feel for the old city, and is a must see.

Jackson Square was only 2 blocks from our hotel. We enjoyed walking there each day and checking out the art and entertainment. It was always a fun, happening place!

Nice afternoon visit to Jackson Square in the heart of New Orleans. Great architecture and picture spot. Offers history and people watching too.

This is a beautiful historical area to see. Right on the riverfront in the french quarter, there is alot of history here. The St. Louis Cathedral is a must see. There are alot of artists here and also a good place to get a carraige ride through the quarter.

It reminded me exactly of NY with similar street performers, artists selling their works, musicians and of course some homeless sprinkled in. It is what it is, not that we didn't like walking around it, looking at the art, listening to some music, but once you've done that, moving on to something else. Not a place I would go to...


More  



Can't add much more than the 5000+ people already have. Great place to see local artists, performers, etc. Always great for Jazz band's playing which is worth the visit. If you are lucky you will run into two street performers playing the drums and bango, totally a great time we listened to them for 1/2 hour. River walk goes right...


More  



The atmosphere here is awesome. If you love art and street performers than this place is for you. Beautiful scenery and interesting people.

Jackson Square was such a cool place to visit! All of the street artists/vendors and the live music, the shopping, the food.....all amazing!!

title: St. Louis Cathedral, New Orleans
address: 615 Pere Antoine Alley, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
Beautiful Cathedral, amazing artwork on the ceiling. But my favourite thing is to sit just outside and listen to the jazz bands.

Absolutely gorgeous architecture, art, stained glass. We lit a few candles for loved ones. Loved the Joan of Arc statue as well. Don't miss it, it really is gorgeous.

We had the opportunity to visit the Cathedral and attend Sunday mass here. I would recommend this for all, Catholic or not, as it is architecturally and spiritually beautiful

This is a beautiful and majestic cathedral in the heart of the French Quarter. The oldest cathedral in the US, it is truly a heritage site.

We were there on a Friday during Lent and even stayed for mass. Very nice church!! Kind of weird to hear all the commotion from the inside of the church, but it is New Orleans after all.

Beautiful architecture!!! Enjoyed our visit to Jackson Square. The street vendors/artists, shopping, amazing food......made for a great day!

It was wonderful to attend Mass on Ash Wednesday. you cant hope but to be inspired by the message. Even If you just peek inside to see this magnificent cathedral make an effort to do so. the murals on the ceiling are beautiful! The most beautiful building in the French Quarter!

What a lovely break from the non stop activity outside its doors.
The ceiling and front alter have beautiful paintings. A must see.

Even if you don't go on the tour this is a gorgeous site to see with history and architecture. It's amazing it's been around and stood the test of time!

We went there for architecture and history. Really enjoyed it. one of the must do in New Orleans. The whole area is quite nice

title: Frenchmen Street, New Orleans
review_list:
We strolled the streets during the day time and enjoyed the music club street scene and unique shops, as well as the different architecture and art work. We stumbled upon a quaint cafe at the end of the clubs. A prime attraction for those seeking a break from the young party scene of Bourbon Street.

We came here on a girls trip to see the French Quarter and were told to check out this area by some locals. I would pick this area over Bourbon Street any day of the week. The musicians were outstanding and there was fabulous art everywhere. This is the place to be!! Visit Snug Harbor, excellent Jazz!!

We stopped by after hearing the great music. Music continued to be awesome and the drafts were really varied and delicious!

If you want a more low-key atmosphere than the chaos of Bourbon street than Frenchmen is a great alternative.

This street is awesome, feel good music, good food, different feel from Bourbon St. More civilized. You'll have a great time! Hop from bar to bar and get to see all kinds of different musicians.

We checked out d.b.a and saw The Iguanas for just $5 cover-fantastic band, highly recommend. Another night enjoyed a street band until it started raining, then we went to Cafe Negril for a reggae band. No cover and band was very crowd interactive, even bringing people on stage to dance. We tipped the band several times as a guy walks...


More  



Everything prior folks have said. Easy walk from Frenchmen's market area. Don't be put off by the look of some of the neighborhood. Who can argue with locals who say it is a must on any trip? Not much going on in the afternoon, looks like 5-7 in evening when things start to happen.

Way more fun than Bourban Street! The spotted cat was fantastic. Lots of music and nice people here and found parking close.

I was hoping Frenchman street wouldn't have the bourbon street type crowds but unfortunately was disappointed it was rather crowded.
If you find a bar or music venue try to park it. Otherwise the street is just too crowded to enjoy yourself.

The Frenchman street area is where the real party happens. Excellent clubs featuring so much great live music; hip arts market
Too.

title: Garden District, New Orleans
review_list:
Nice restaurants, mature trees, can walk around or take the tramway train to downtown.
The Audubon Park is right by. A very different beat than the French Quarter.

The Garden District is filled with wonderful historic houses built during the Victorian era. Most of them have been lovingly and beautifully restored. Unfortunately, because of the extensive roots of the gorgeous trees on St. Charles, the sidewalks are very uneven and you need to watch where you are walking unless you want to risk a bad fall. It's a...


More  



Many people think the parades all travel down Bourbon, but because of the narrow streets, the Garden District is where the parties take place. It is filled with many historical mansions, cemeteries, and restaurants, and is a great base for your trip to the Big Easy!

Avoid the trolley if you can. It was completely crowded and worth the extra $ to take a cab/uber, at least one way.

Take the trolley to the Garden District and then just walk the area - so many beautiful homes with so much history!! I just wish we could have gone inside one (or more) to see what they are like inside!

The area has beautiful architecture. Make sure to stop by the homes of Anne Rice and John Goodman. The Lafayette cemetery is located in the center of the district and is open to all. If possible, plan for a brunch at Commander's Palace. It's worth every penny.

If it's a pretty day when you are dining at Commander's Palace, be sure to grab a map from the front lobby and take a self-guided walking tour through the Garden District. Beautiful mansions and the historic Lafeyette Graveyard offer opportunities for the amateur photographer to get some great pictures as well as for the scholar to learn some Louisiana...


More  



Take the tours! There is do much history and wonderful stories. A lot of walking so wear comfy shoes. A lot of uneven ground so be careful.

Get on the street car and feast your eyes on elegance as you travel along St. Charles Street. Then get off the street car and walk amidst the grandeur of days past. There are too many gorgeous home to take in - but you can get a sense of just how grand it was and is to live in this...


More  



The best way to experience this lovely district, short of knowing someone who lives in the neighborhood, is to ride the streetcar through it, getting off and walking for long stretches. Houses have unique features blended with classic New Orleans designs.

title: French Quarter, New Orleans
address: Canal St to Esplanade Ave, Mississippi River to N Rampart St, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
If you visit New Orleans, don't miss the "Quarter." Rich with history and charm, there's simply nothing like it in the US.

No visit to the city is complete without strolling the French Quarter, smelling the odors, eating the fine cuisine, enjoying the architecture and polite nature of the residents.

Even though it was after Mardi Gras was over there was so much going on in the French Quarter while we were there. So many different stores to go to with a great variety of things to buy. Anything from Mardi Gras gear, voodoo, vampires, ghosts, plus so much history. I absolutely loved it and we spent the whole day...


More  



We came to the French Quarter on a girls vacation. Wow, what an experience!! Talented street musicians, fabulous food, wonderful art, etc. Absolutely loved every minute of it.

Every single time I end up in the Quarter...for a conference or a cruise ship...I have a good time! Can't help but love it. Always highly recommended. Just remember, as it gets later, the crowd gets younger and rowdier!

If you go to New Orleans, you need to have the experience of the French Quarter, for sure. The buildings, the colors with all the different structure and a lot of them decorated for the occasion: Mardi Gras, St-Patrick's Day, Easter. For me, that was Louisiana!!

The French Quarter offers a feast for the eyes, mouth watering food for the taste, joyous music for the ears, holding hands with your Love for the touch. You can get nitty gritty or fancy smanchy... what ever your taste this place offers it all!

A great place to go if you are looking for the authentic New Orleans atmosphere. Loved all the shops and street performers.

The colors, attraction getting items & people's...there are no holes barred. The fantastic restaurants & shops are a must.

Great place to people watch and drink. Keep your valuables close as there are pickpockets. Stay aware at all times. During the day, it was much more family friendly. At night, it got weird (but in a good way). The further down Bourbon you travel, the darker it gets...

title: New Orleans City Park, New Orleans
review_list:
Beautiful park, easy access by trolley. Storyland was cute for pre-schoolers. Park is huge and botanic gardens are beautiful.

City Park has something for everyone: young, old, and in-between! You won't be disappointed!
Storyland, amusement ride area, sculpture park, places to eat, miles and miles of greenery, ponds, walking trails, Put-Put mini golf course,

This park is a very large park. take a stroll, take some time and enjoy it. There are several ponds. The Café in the center is very good and a great place for lunch.

wonderful park - grand sensory experiences - water features, magnificent old trees, cafe - beignets!!

City park is a great place to get away from the craziness of the city and you can even get there by bike. Not only MUST you savor the coffee and beignets and alligator sausage at the Morning Call; you can wander the grounds and enjoy the sculpture garden. You can also paddle a swanboat or listen to live jazz....


More  



Was there in October which is a beautiful time of year. We made a picnic lunch and had a wonderful time. Just make sure you take a little extra for the birds. Not much or they will get greedy.

Go here if you want old-fashioned fun. I highly recommend the miniature train and amusement area in the southernmost part of the park.

I've seen urban parks in many cities and this is probably the most spectacular. With all the big oak trees snd the bridges and the sculpture garden. Do not miss it!

Attended a wedding at The pavilion of the Two Sisters in City Park, New Orleans. What a phenomenal venue for a wedding. Set up in the garden of the pavilion in from of a beautiful fountain surrounded by dancing candles gave the ceremony a most beautiful glow. Ceremony was followed by a reception in the pavilion. Simple but beautiful. Large...


More  



I have lived in Louisiana all of my life and this park is fabulous, My husband and i enjoy the sculpture garden, its gorgeous! This is a MUST SEE if you are in New orleans!

title: Preservation Hall, New Orleans
address: 726 St. Peter Street, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
Pre booked seats a month in advance. Absolutely mesmerized. Had friends with us who I wasn't sure would take to it. They placed it as a highlight in NOLA. Great way to end Mardi Gras week

The door people were generous and adjusted the price of entry when we showed up late. We were then only 10 rows back from the band. These musicians were incredible! We saw Leroy Jones' band... he's the lead trumpet player for Harry Connick Jr's Big band.

We had to get in line for tickets almost an hour before show. It was our last night in New Orleans and I wanted to make sure we got in. My husband and I were out 8 year old son. We wanted to enjoy some jazz and heard this place was definitely kid friendly. We got into the venue. One...


More  



Went last week, Brilliant !!
Worth paying the extra if they are available for the Vip seats
No waiting in line and the best seats in the house

The music is good in the barely-one hour shows. Know beforehand that, unless you get tickets early in the day, that you'll pay $15 to stand, with no drinks, in a crowd.

Stand in line and wait - original New Orleans jazz music. This was the most authentic part of our excusion to the Big Easy. The best hour spent in the French Quarter.

A tiny room, so authentically old, you might think it was created by Disney, but this is genuine. We worried that such a storied show would be canned/phony; the reality is these guys just so love to play that it is fresh and joyful. Great musicians, even by my professional musician wife's standards.
It's a tiny room, so there are...


More  



Buy tickets early if you can! We waited until a week or two before our visit to look into tickets, and they were already sold out. Purchasing tickets in advance will secure a seat, otherwise you have to wait in line and hope you can get in. We got to Preservation Hall at 7:00 for an 8:00 show and there...


More  



We waited in line for 45 minutes to get in and were lucky enough to get a seat on the cushion in the front row (although my husband now regrets not standing because his leg fell asleep 5 minutes into the show). Tickets are $15, and the show is an hour long. There is no a.c., no bar, no bathroom,...


More  



This was #1 on my list and I'm glad we did it. $20 for standing room. I couldn't see a thing but I didn't need to - the band sounded great. It was cool to stand in this place! Nothing pretty about it except the music and the music was enough.

title: The Sydney and Walda Besthoff Sculpture Garden at NOMA, New Orleans
address: 1 Collins C. Diboll Circle, City Park, New Orleans, LA 70124
review_list:
A short cab ride from the French Quarter is the NOLA art museum and this sculpture garden is just next to it. A delightful way to spend an hour or an hour and a half. Good assortment of a few great artists (Moore, Hepworth, Renoir, etc.) and many more contemporary works.

we went there after a visit to the Museum of Modern Art(NOMA)and we couldnt believe such a free exhibition, outdoor, surrounded by trees, fountains, a perfect outdoor activity.

We went here on our last day in New Orleans. So glad we did. A lot of really impressive pieces. The setting of the garden is peaceful and calm and such a pleasant respite from an otherwise frenetic city. I highly recommend this garden as it was such a surprise and it is a very high quality and sophisticated collection.

An amazing eclectic collection of sculptures presented in a lovely garden setting. Suitable for all ages. Relaxing and interesting. And free. Take the streetcar to City Park.

So many of the sculptures make you stop and think for a minute. Beautiful place to walk around! There is no charge for entrance and it is easily accessible by the street cars- get off at the final stop on the City Park line.

We enjoyed exploring City Park for a couple of hours on a Friday afternoon. The sculptures were interesting and varied. Our entire group enjoyed exploring the grounds. Afterwards walked over the bridge to get beignets & cafe au lair/hot chocolate.

Wow! My husband and I were very impressed with the beautiful Besthoff Sculpture Garden. The fine collection of sculpture, installed among such natural beauty, was exciting to see. We highly recommend strolling through this special place when in New Orleans.

Some nice art to gaze at in a nice little park setting - was very enjoyable, went to go to the museum on a Monday only to find it closed, but this garden was open - and very glad I went to enjoy it

We strolled through the sculpture park on a beautiful Sunday afternoon in January and were delighted by our discovery. The park is very well laid out and each sculpture has its place in the sun. We have seen work by many of these artists elsewhere, but never have we seen quality work by so many reknowned artists in a single...


More  



It was a beautiful day, which never hurts when you're visiting an outdoor area.
I'm not generally a big fan of sculpture parks, but this one has such variety that it would be difficult to not find something you like. Easy to walk by the style that doesn't appeal to you and then linger at those that do.
And if...


More

title: RTA - Streetcars, New Orleans
review_list:
If you want to experience the city first hand, you must take a ride on the cities Streetcars. No, they aren't trolleys! They offer convenient routes through the French Quarter, waterfront, and Garden District, and are an excellent way to see the city from street level.

It's hard to rate the streetcars because it really is a must for any first time visitor. If the city is busy though, it's also a huge pain. They need some serious help in the operations department...
PROS -
- Inexpensive way to get around the city
- The mobile app is great - download the app, pay for your...


More  



Definitely a good way to get across town for cheap and a cool way to do so in a classic streetcar. It did take nearly 30 minutes to get from Harrah's to City Park. The cars generally arrived on schedule but sometimes there was a decent wait between cars.

I love the convenience and accessibility of the streetcars, I use them often when I am in New Orleans. The best way to get around especially if you are taking part in libations

Our hotel was right on the streetcar stop. We literally just had to walk out and get into the streetcar. They are an amazing way of getting around in the city. Get the $3 day pass and enjoy unlimited rides on all the streetcars and buses

You can't beat the price at $3 for a day pass. The streetcars on the main arteries like St. Charles and along Canal street are pretty frequent. The Riverwalk like seemed to run less frequently. Some of the operators were real characters!

A day pass is just $3.00 or just $.40/ride for seniors. For this meager amount you can ride the rails and see the city from an iconic vantage point. We took it to Mandina's, to church in the Garden District, and to brunch at Panola Street Cafe. It runs all night and is a great way to feel connected to...


More  



We used the street cars as much as possible. You can get around so easy. We rode tje street car to the grave yard and to the garden district and the river front...great transportation.

It isn't difficult to find a streetcar in New Orleans or route guides. All the hotels have a map. There are signs at stops. You must have correct change however.

Great way to get around New Orleans. Parking is expensive all over town, so leave your car at your hotel and use the streetcars.

title: Jamie Hayes Gallery, New Orleans
review_list:
Love this gallery. Bought several pieces and a great shirt. This man is very talented and his work is unique. Chartres and Royal streets offer many galleries but be sure to stop in this one. It's different and very interesting.

Enjoyed looking at all of the art and bought several things. I even bought an adult coloring book of his drawings. Great fun.

Everything in the store is signed by the artist very colorful, unique a little pricy for the larger pieces of art nice little boutique.

Jamie Hayes is a fabulous artist! If you are into color, and a lot going on with your art, this is the gallery for you! Such fun in all of his works.

We spent a fascinating hour in Jamie's gallery enjoying his whimsical and enchanting art, embarking on a colourful journey with him in English and German. Author, illustrator, and creator of "Up in The Air", a children's book about playful characters travelling in an airship, the Zeppelin, Jamie engaged us in an enlightening conversation about one of his favourite subjects. We...


More  



Interesting art objects to get for gifts........posters......voodoo dolls....tee shirts.....always good music playing and most often Jamie is there working on a project

Painter proprietor took time go speak to us about the art and blues! Well worth stopping by to see him!!!! A short walk into the Quarter!

We have two prints from Jamie Hayes including the Chili Pepper Kitty and the Smoking Club. He has so many great visions to choose from, all fabulous and original. We also bought t-shirts of the dressed alligator New Orleans Po-Boy. Classics!

I highly recommend a stop at the Jamie Hayes Gallery as you walk around the French Quarter. The vibrancy of his work is best seen in person and if the art doesn't make you smile, your heart is cold and closed! 😉 Seriously, choose some Jamie Hayes artwork to take home with you, rather than another Saints T-shirt or giant...


More  



Jamie Hayes gallery is a fun place. I love his art. I was a bit disappointed with the t-shirts for ladies. Not much to select from and sized varied widely depending on the manufacturer.

title: Audubon Park, New Orleans
review_list:
Beautiful park full of mature oak trees and Spanish moss. Located across from the zoo and easily accessible by tramway (street car). Nice walking path. Bring a lunch, sit on a bench and contemplate.g

What a relaxing place to walk around. Different stuff to see and so nice to walk around. No need to like hiking to go check out this park.

New Orleans, smell is in the air. The Food, the Flowers, the fragrance. Beautiful, quiet walks among the flora and fauna

Nice park, amazing trees good for a bike ride. Streetcar green line take you there from Canal Street. The Zoo us there too.

This park is beautiful and peaceful. If you want a jog in the park, go here. There are a lot of ducks and birds on bird island.

A walk through Audubon Park is beautiful and relaxing. We sat on benches and watched the wildlife. Well worth visiting.

Beautiful park with grand old oak tress, ponds, ducks, and a playground for the kids. We only visited the northern end and had very little time but it was quiet and enjoyable. A nice slow down and free!

This park is great for strollers and bikers. Lots of room with huge oaks and spanish moss for some great photos. Walk behind the zoo to the "Fly" where you can sit on the grass and watch the tugboats go up and down the river. Enjoy!

Great park to go for a walk or a bike ride. Also you can walk to the zoo from the school. Great houses around the perimeter of the park.

While on the St. Charles street car, we saw this park and stopped to check it out. The park is very large. They have a jogging and biking trail. Lots of beautiful trees and plantings, a few statues, a pond with lots of birds and many benches to sit and relax. It was a great place up get away from...


More

title: Immaculate Conception Church, New Orleans
review_list:
5 stars for beauty. If you're in New Orleans, this is a must see. It may be a "tourist" thing to do, but it's worth it to see this amazing building built for worship.

Located just across from Dominica in the Roosevelt Hotel, this church is stunning. Just walking by you may miss it if you didn't look up and dee the domes. The inside is amazing and well worth a detour in your NOLA visit.

When you walk into this awe inspiring church, you immediately become quiet while taking it all in.You are encouraged to quietly check out the whole church. It was a nice chance to unwind after the incredible high energy of the city!

This is a Jesuit Church, and great for attending Mass. Double check the times during wedding season as this a popular place to get married.

I loved this church! I went to mass at 8:00 a.m. on a Sunday. No music but I liked that - it made it much more solemn for me. The priest (mass was on 1/31) gave a FANTASTIC homily. He was so point with the realities of what Christian love means. The church is also very beautiful - murals were...


More  



Nestled in between two buildings is this gem of a church. Very historic but well maintained. Caught the tail end of Mass and it was beautifully done. Some wonderful pictures of Mary and statues. Architecture lovers will enjoy this church.

Beautiful church to visit while in the city. The mass is always done by a Jesuit priest. Cannot miss an opportunity to view this magnificent place of worship.

We went to 4:00 pm Mass on Saturday since we were dining at Domica right across the street and the Mardi Gras parades were closing Canal Street to traffic and making it difficult to get out of the French Quarter. The church is lovely and well maintained and worth a vissit.

As the other reviews have already describe this is a very beautiful church and a must stop for all Catholics.

terrific old cathedral. beautifully preserved and well worth visiting -- especially loved the magnificent stained glass.

title: Metairie Cemetery, New Orleans
address: 5100 Pontchartrain Blvd., Open 8am-5pm, Onsite parking, Handicap Access, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
Beautiful, peaceful cemetary. Easy to get to but don't confuse the cemetary at the end of the trolley line as Metairie. You have to cross the street and walk left to the underpass.

You find the cemetery buries its relatives in above ground vaults due to flooding in the area. We found one of a boo-doo priestess.

The Metairie Cemetery is the home of the famous Weeping Angel. The angel is inside the tomb with blue stained glass. The rest of the cemetery is beautiful and very interesting. Lots of other interesting markers. I recommend taking the street car to get there.

This is a fascinating place. Won't take long, but don't miss it. Be sure you have a tour guide to explain everything. Great for photographers.

This is a very large cemetry. It has wonderfully ostentatious mausoleums alongside more humble ones. The fallen angel is worth seeking out - she immediately impressions.

I spent a couple of hours taking photographs in this amazing cemetery. The location is a little scary and difficult to walk to versus the other cemeteries at the end of the Canal Streetcar line, but the Mateirie Cemetery is much more interesting and has many more unique and picturesque statues and mausoleums to photograph.

We chose this cemetery over the small town one. It is very peaceful, and pretty big. You can drive or walk around, plenty of space to just park the car anywhere. On a sunny day it's absolutely beautiful, and a very different sight to a traditional cemetery. If you get into the main building, the staff can provide you with...


More  



beautiful cemetery..feeling safe all the time I was there... serenity and neatness abound..... not sure when I will return but I feel safe at this cemetery.

The Metairie Cemetery is the home of the famous Weeping Angel. She is not easy to find, so here are some directions: go to the Lake Street entrance and look for a dead end with two rounded cement pillars. The angel is inside the tomb with blue stained glass. The rest of the cemetery is beautiful and very interesting. Visitors...


More  



On my last visit I discovered this hidden gem. The cemetery is very safe and well kept. It is a little hard to get into so look at a map closely. Once you are in it is an amazing place. The final resting place for many here are nothing short of art. The statues and stain glass in the mausoleums...


More

title: Historic New Orleans Collection, New Orleans
review_list:
Just off the busy Royal Street. Absolutely taken aback by this extraordinary collection of artifacts from 17th 18th 19th centuries focused on Louisiana and New Orleans. Many old maps. Two gorgeous portraits of Andrew Jackson.

There is always something worthwhile here. Their bookshop / gift shop is lovely. The downstairs exhibit changes, so even if you are a frequent visitor to New Orleans, stop by to see what's there. The house tour is a bargain at $5. And, it is very interesting -- without Kemper and Leila Williams there would not be a French Quarter...


More  



My husband and I stumbled onto this while we were looking at the internal courtyard. Upstairs is a small museum with great information about the history of the city. Worth a visit - in the short 15 minute visit we learnt quite a bit about the city and its french influences.

Nestled among the upscale shops and restaurants along vibrant Royal Street in the French Quarter is a collection of historic buildings, courtyards and galleries that present a visitor with totally different experience than the celebratory norm. The Historic New Orleans Collection is a "museum, research center and publisher" anchored by two main gallery complexes in the French Quarter, one the...


More  



I originally discovered their exhibits, tours and bookshop about ten years ago and have a membership. It should be a required stop for anyone interested in historical events in New Orleans. They have a permanent exhibit of paintings and decorative arts, a changing exhibit on the ground floor of the Royal Street building on a selected topic, a great bookstore...


More  



Great collection that covers New Orleans history with great breadth and depth. Most of the exhibits are free and the staff is very friendly.
New Orleans is a city with a large range of political and cultural complexity over a 400 year span and this collection covers it all.
They have a number of building in the Quarter that can...


More  



If you didn't know it was there, you'd walk right past this museum. It hardly looks like anything from the street, but inside is a luxurious entry, intriguing exhibits and docents among the most knowledgeable I've found anywhere. The history of Louisiana is told through maps, artwork, story boards, videos and, most importantly, the people who wait for you in...


More  



We stopped in here with two hours allotted. We will be going back. Great privately funded, public and free! Staff are very knowledgeable and provide phenomenal historical insight and context on New Orleans - from the 17th century, through the Louisana purchase, the war of 1812 and more. If you want to know more about the USA, American history and...

title: Confederacy of Cruisers Bike Tours, New Orleans
review_list:
Nick our guide was excellent. His depth of knowledge was great and his sense of humour had you relaxed straight away. Bikes we're comfortable and smooth to ride. Pace of trip was just right. Great way to see parts of the City you'd otherwise miss. Can't recommend them enough

Forget the streetcar. The only way to really see New Orleans is on two wheels. Our guide, Nick, led us on a bicycle tour through historic neighborhoods far from the manufactured hoopla of Bourbon Street. This was the coolest thing we did in NOLA!

The best way to view the sites on bikes, not a tour bus. The tour included historical info, while peddling along on the flat land and added so much more appreciation for the are. Jeff was an excellent guide with strong knowledge of the area's history, and love for New Orleans.

title: New Orleans Museum of Art, New Orleans
address: 1 Collin Diboll Circle, New Orleans, LA 70124
review_list:
This museum has a small number of important pieces, yet gives a good breadth of African, American, Asian and contemporary art. A highlight was a walk through the sculpture park, which include a Henry Moore and a Botero, as well as about fifty others, many which were evocative and inspired conversation.

Surprising gems of Art: Cassatt, Monet, Degas, Pissarro, etc. and many more Renaissance and Modern artists. Beautifully maintained and a nice café to retire to afterwards.

New Orleans is such a great place to see Art. New Orleans is art in itself but the museum always has such fine art. I highly recommend going there.

I did not know what to expect when I went here. The environment was certainly beautiful, as it is in the middle of CIty Park. The museum had several interesting small special exhibits that I enjoyed. But the third floor really surprised me....don't miss it. The African collection is excellent. And the cafe is quite good. I was able to...


More  



Lovely museum with beautiful variety of pieces. Nice date location. Only takes a couple hours. Immaculately clean and kept.

Thoroughly enjoyed our visit. Good range of art. Nice cafe with reasonably priced food. Easy to get to using the streetcar. Visit the outdoor sculpture gallery (free) while you're there

The New Orleans Museum of Art is located in City Park. It's not a giant museum so you can see the exhibits in a few hours. The exhibits seem to change on a regular basis so what you see today will not be what you see next week or month.
When we were there, the exhibits went from Impressionist paintings,...


More  



We spent a couple of hours viewing the collection. An interesting collection. The gardens are well worth walking round with some interesting sculputures.

We only had time for the sculpture garden but it was a great display of modern and ancient art from many famous sculptors. Very engaging, edgy even , and something that broadens your knowledge and spurs your imagination. Wonderful creativity on display for the curious and imaginative. Get away from the crowds and Bourbon Street and see this for a...


More  



The collection has a bit of everything: Italian Renaissance to modern photography. There are a few Impressionists of interest and some period furniture. It is set in a nice park easily reached by public transportation. There is a sculpture garden and a nice cafe.

This is a wonderful place where Saints play & very family oriented place to plan - Right in the middle of New Orleans downtown close to all the fun places

The Superdome has renovated the bathrooms in recent years, and the fares at the concession stands have been upgraded. The concourse can be rather cramped during sold-out events, but thats to be expected.

So convenient to downtown and the French Quarter. Amazing building with very pleasant and professional staff. Every Super Bowl should be played here.

The Superdome looks awesome. It's not as busy as the French Quarter unless there's a game but it's nice to see it restored.

title: Saenger Theatre, New Orleans
review_list:
This theater is centrally located. The architecture is beautiful. Once you walk in, you are transported to a different place and time.

So very glad that after years of being shuttered due to Hurricane Katrina, the Saenger is finally open. The theater offers a wide range of entertainment including Broadway shows, music concerts, comedy concerts, etc. Parking is easy and plentiful, lots of lots nearby and you can usually find a spot on the street if needed. Staff are very friendly and...


More  



We attended Motown the Musical and our experience was wonderful. The attendants were very efficient and the lines to get in moved quickly. We had very good seats and the show started promptly at 8pm. It was one of the best musicals that I'd seen. The talent was phenomenal! The Saenger was beautiful and very well kept. I'd like to...


More  



Find a reason to attend a performance here just to get inside and see the beautiful restoration work that was done to this theatre. Its worth the price of a ticket just to see how lovingly it has been restored. We saw "Motown" (which was great) but honestly it doesn't matter. Just go! You will not be disappointed.

We went to the Saenger for a play and it was a wonderful experience! If you are looking for a smaller venue with good seats and acoustics this is the place!

My wife and I came here for here Christmas present to see Beauty and the Beast. The lines to get in moved very quickly, and our seats at the back of the orchestra area were great for visibility.
All staff were courteous and helpful. The acoustics of the place were great on this occasion and for every other visit. The...


More  



This was my second trip to the Saenger and the first for my mother and 5 year old daughter. My girl was fascinated by the "stars" on the ceiling. The entire theatre is beautiful a the staff is very efficient in directing the masses of people entering. I love that the downstairs bathroom has so many stalls. Even if there...


More  



Recently attended the traveling Broadway production of Beauty and the Beast at the Saenger. It is as elegant and sophisticated as I remembered from childhood. There are some interior traffic flow issues but I expect that's the case with most historic theatres. I also wonder how handicap accessible it is? Had a lovely time nonetheless.

We saw the Dancing with the Stars Tour here and loved this beautiful theater. Nice seating. Gorgeous architecture.

We had tickets to the Dancing with the Stars. We parked at the garage across a side street with a sign for parking for the Saenger and the Orpheum. $20 - not bad for the city. Walked right over - lots of people, no fears at all - just my daughter and me. We had seats on the aisle -...


More

title: Magazine Street, New Orleans
review_list:
Cute shopping/eating area and beautiful houses. Recommend against the trolley on a weekend, it was overcrowded and waited for 2 trolleys before we could get on. Standing room only.

Spend your tourist-obligatory 30 minutes taking pictures on Bourbon Street, then walk around Jackson Square, then escape to Magazine Street. It is a long and exciting journey to some of the more unique shops and finer restaurants (Peche Seafood Grill, Coquette, Shaya, Le Petite Grocery, Apolline, ...and the list goes on and on) and more fun bars/pubs (Salu, Rhum House...too...


More  



Treasured by locals to offer a wide range of stores, restaurants / clubs, this is the place to see artisans at work, hand crafted items from fashions, shoes, leather goods, to brass gaslights. Antique shops in abundance ! Recommend you bring a vehicle with a large trunk / cargo hold and arrive mid morning to start the journey along this...


More  



Walk along Magazine for as long as you wish, several miles of it, stop and shop, window shop, drink coffee, eat great food and enjoy the architecture and history.

Magazine Street is where you want to go for anything you can possibly think of. Fashion, food, the usual (CVS and Walgreens), the not so usual (Fleurty Girl - for all things New Orleans), to the somewhat huh? On a lovely day it is fun to just stroll up one side and return down the other. Luckily the Big Bus...


More  



Heard a lot about Magazine street but the day we visited it must have been the wettest day since the great flood! We were not disappointed and it certainly has a lot to offer!

We like to tour the Magazine St. area on our bike rides... There are lots of good restaurants and shops along the way...

It has been well over two decades since I visited Magazine Street. All of the changes have been positive. One can find anything they want or didn't now they wanted in the shops. Very peasant and right by the Garden District.

This is an upscale area you can walk through with a lot of high end shops and restaurants. We thoroughly enjoyed eating pizza at Theo's on Magazine Street.

This is the most authentic, and most friendly, flag shop that I have ever been to! If you want a real New Orleans place with native New Orleanians, and you want owners that are friendly with the widest selection of beautiful and unique flags, I strongly recommend this place! Charles is like royalty in New Orleans, especially in the uptown...


More

title: Backstreet Cultural Museum, New Orleans
address: 1116 Henriette Delille, New Orleans, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
This was very interesting and the history shared on the local culture was great. The Mardi Gras Indian costumes are so elaborate and amazing. I would highly recommend this.

This museum about black indians tradition in New Orleans has a very large of local suits and other countries traditional costumes. I was surprised when I saw a Jacmel's Carnival picture in the museum.

Unusual collection of Afro-American costume with lots of artifacts from days gone by. Talk to the hosts - they're full of information and deeply involved. Recommended if you want to experience culture. Not expensive.

I would highly recommend a visit here for anyone interested in learning more about New Orleans' unique and diverse culture. This place gives a great example of the Mardi Gras Indian traditions and how meaningful they are to the African American population of the city. And having just this small, but authentic example of a museum to the tradition is...


More  



This museum is an absolute delight.
By itself the array of ornate Mardi Gras Indian costumes and related paraphernalia, including imagery of jazz funerals, is something to behold. But the guided tour makes everything come alive. The sweat and toil of the costume making, the parading, the critiquing and the hierarchy – all give a greater understanding of this significant...


More  



If you got a taste of the Indians from HBO's Treme or aren't in town when they are parading, then get over to the Treme to see Mr Francis' collection and talk with him about the history of the Indians and the costume artistry. Nice sample of Second line costumes and information as well.

Its a small place, costs $8 cash only. But we were surprised to see so many parade costumes, and the person who made them. They are very beautiful and amazing! Worth the trip!

This is a quaint, small museum filled with Mardi Gras Regalia and a great opportunity to learn about the history of Indians and their roll in NOLA history. Nice visit for the family. It's small so you can do the tour in an hour.

This wonderful museum is indispensable to any visit to New Orleans. It shows the roots of the culture, especially the music culture, based in Carnival traditions like Mardi Gras Indians, Skull& Bones gang, and Baby Dolls.

If you have any interest in the Indian costumes and culture, this place is a must. With luck, the young woman - great granddaughter of one of the queens - will give you a very informative tour of the place with detailed information about the tribes and their customs.

title: Ogden Museum of Southern Art, New Orleans
review_list:
Marie Hull was a Mississippi artist who displayed a great depth to her painting. Landscapes, birds, flowers and portraits are among the many things she painted. This special exhibit just opened Feb 20 and runs thru the end of May. There will also be a special opening exhibit reception Saturday March 12 from 7-9pm. We didn't know anything about here...


More  



The museum has an eclectic and interesting collection of modern art. The collection is well organized, unique, and very open to emerging artists.

Interesting exhibits from local artists. Attractive displays. Fun venue with music on Thursday evenings.

If you want to see "Southern art", go here. This is a nice smallish collection of some lovely art. You can comfortably see everything in about an hour.

As artists ourselves, we always seek out the galleries and museums wherever we go. We walked from the French Quarter and took the trolley back. The collection was not only impressive, but well presented. Beautifulll setting, unique architecture, modern amenities, and an excellent representation of Southern Art. Visit here as well as the New Orleans Museum of Art. You'll get...


More  



I noticed that most of the reviews were positive in reflection of this museum, and honestly I do not know why. The only floor worth looking at was the 2nd. The rest was horrible, distastful, and I seriously think the staff should warn visitors of the graphics and what it represents on the 5th floor. I've been to many other...


More  



All 50 of the sculptures are labeled and you get a map or audio tour to use. This garden is free. You can get there by bus or streetcar.

While I've visted New Orleans many times, this was the first time I made it to this museum. Very nicely laid out with many different types of artwork displayed. Allow 2 hours to enjoy the exhibit. Just a block away from the WW2 museum.

Ogden is a very attractive museum with a collection that does a nice job of displaying Southern art. They cover it with admirable depth and breadth. It should be enjoyed for how well it serves its mission, which is very well.
I liked the photo exhibits and the ones dealing with social conflict.
It should be visited.

The Ogden Museum which is near the World War II Museum is another must-see. They have paintings and decorative arts in the permanent collection and special shows of southern and Louisiana arts. The building is modern and beautiful and is a treat for art lovers.

title: French Market, New Orleans
address: Decatur St, 1100 North Peters, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
A variety of food options appealing to all, live music, local and world goods for purchase - the market has it all. Plan to spend some time to relax and see everything, and chat with the vendors while enjoying the unique atmosphere. Public restrooms nearby.

There was definitely a lot of things to see, buy, eat, and much more there. So much variety you don't know where to start. The weather was beautiful the day we went so it was very packed. It does get a little hectic then because you have to maneuver around everyone. But overall a great place to go.

If you stopped by Cafe Du Monde, you'll want to saunter up the street to the East to the French Market to do a little shopping. Lots of interesting and not-so-interesting items, people and food to partake of. If you dig a little, you'll find some great bargains and REALLY interesting vendors. I found a guy there that had some...


More  



French Market parking had easy access (once you wound thru the narrow streets) and was convenient to the shopping and eating places, but do not advertise their rates as you enter. We parked for about 3 hours and paid $49. Maybe that is par for that area, but was quite surprised. It is safe parking and near the riverboat dockings.

From the array of bottled hot sauces, to local dishes (picnic style), and the ever present T-shirt sellers, this place also offers book stores, higher end ceramics, clothes and hats, and many Asian type stalls with jewelry, watches, etc. A good place to shop (prices better than Bourbon ST). Quirky and fun !

My husband and I took a walk down to the market one afternoon. There were so many different food vendors, it was great to have so many options. We grabbed some sandwiches and sat at a table, enjoyed the breeze and a leisurely lunch. I want very excited about the clothing, but there were some local artists set up there...


More  



Whether you are a person who likes to shop or not, the French Market is a place you have to visit at least once. There is something for everyone. Its like a flea market but with really good food. You will find all kinds of NOLA tshirts, handmade masks, paintings (which you can often see a local artist there working...


More  



The French market was recommended to us on a food tour so we spent our lunch exploring the food and offerings of the market. We had the best muffuletta of our trip in the market, was amazing! There was lots of local produce and souvenirs to buy and look at. Was a great place to spend the afternoon!

One of the staples of any trip to New Orleans. It's an easy stroll thru all the booths. You can pick up some inexpensive souvenirs ranging from clothing to hand made art pieces. There are some upscale items as well, but the main attraction for me has always been the food. From grilled corn on the cob served street-food style...


More  



Alright, sure... it's filled with lots of trinkets and wares that you probably could find online, but heck - you've gotta' pick up a few novelties for the folks back home while you're visiting, right? Well... it's worth it to go at least once while in the French Quarter!
Everything from Alligator Bites (food) to Handmade Soaps and every type...


More

title: Louis Armstrong Park, New Orleans
address: 901 North Rampart Street, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
A place for jazz lovers to be nostalgic and enjoy sculptures and beautiful landscaping. The park has a moving statue of Louis Armstrong himself. It is a nice place to stroll, but is north of the French Quarter, so don't plan to find much else there.

Nice place to walk and relax with different fountain and little bridges, cute and you can bring your kiddos and check it out.

Get away from the hustle of Bourbon Street for a bit and enjoy the quiet waters and sculpture in Louis Armstrong Park. There were no concerts when we visited, but we enjoyed walking around the park and looking at the sculptures.

Getting ready for the Barkus parade when we were there so full of interestingly dressed dogs. Still a pleasant place to walk on a Sunday morning.

Very clean. Park has many sculptures to take pictures with. Also has a pond and plenty of space to sit down. Not a very big one, could be a quick walk through, but located right next to the French Quarter.

What a great park to experience Lois Armstrong. The Park lights at night are great.The Arway is memorable.

This is a great place to wander! Even though there wasn't music playing, we could sense the jazz in the sculptures and loved learning about the cultural importance of the park!

Louis Armstrong park was on our walk home between Treme and the French quarter. We walked through it several times, it was lovely and clean. Beautiful park. A couple of times there was live music and events happening. Plenty of places to sit, plenty to see!

The Louis Armstrong Park is surrounded by Public Housing Units, and constitutes a Safety RISK. Not recommended for non-locals.

I parked near here (one of the few places you won't get a ticket!) and visited. Not much here save some jazz art and some unimpressive water features.
Oh...and more drunks. Is there any place in New Orleans where these poor folks don't congregate?

title: Louisiana State Museum (The 1850 House), New Orleans
address: 523 St Ann Street, Lower Pontalba Building, Jackson Square, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
This museum has a highly interesting, multi-media, in-depth and multi-perspective look at the geographical history of the area and the enormous impact of Hurricane Katrina.

My boyfriend and I visited the museum after stopping at The Presbytere first and loved all the historical information we absorbed. it was great to see all the different artifacts on display and turn learn about the history of Louisiana!

This is a don't miss attraction on Jackson Square. The first floor is an outstanding exhibit of the Katrina hurricane of 2005 in which over 1,000 people lost their lives. The second floor is the history of Mardi Gras in New Orleans with beautiful costumes .

I think entry was around $6 so it was totally worth it. I was the most interested in the Hurricane Katrina stuff and found it fascinating. The upper level was the history of Mardi Gras which I'm still confused about but interesting nonetheless. If you are in Jackson Square stop in and check it out. I don't know if I...


More  



Visited this museum at Jackson square. I mostly did the Katrina exposition. I liked it but after the spectacular WW II museum this one is a bit too ordinary for me, no matter how sad, depressing and hopeful the topic is

The museum part was closed when we visited, but we explored the gift shop and the staff was helpful answering questions.

We learned so much about NOLA visiting this place! It's worth the money to visit. Cost is less than $10 per person. Just takes a couple of hours to take it all in. Nice afternoon excursion.

We just went into the Presbytère. There are multiple museums. In this one we saw the Katrina and Mardi Gras exhibits. They were both excellent and the entrance fee was quite reasonable.

The Louisiana State Museum has a number of fascinating properties. I got to see the Mint which has great jazz exhibits and the Cabildo which has a great exhibit on the history of rock n roll in Louisiana.

Enjoyed visiting this museum. Very interesting and educational displays. It is a self guided museum so you can take your time. The price is only $6.00. If you purchase a ticket to the Cabildo museum you get a 20% discount on both museum tickets. It took us about 2-3 hours to visit both museums. Both museums are located near Jackson...


More

title: St. Augustine Church, New Orleans
review_list:
We went to the 10AM mass. The choir and band were great and the sermon down to earth. The Parishoners were very open to visitors. The Church is only a block up from the French Quarter. We walked and it seemed plenty safe to us. Definitely visit the tomb of the unknown slave on the right side of church (if...


More  



We went to St Augustine Church for Christmas Eve Mass and were not disappointed. The choir and band were wonderful. The people in the church were so friendly and accepting. Enjoyed the mass a lot. Thank you for letting us join in the celebration

Does not matter what religion you are a visit to St Augustine is just what the soul needs. It is a traditional Catholic mass with a great choir - full band and great piano - at Communion all religions are welcome to come for a blessing. This is a real dose of real New Orleans and the great people of...


More  



I had the pleasure of attending a free gospel concert in St. Augustine Church recently. The concert was part of New Orleans' free holiday concert series. Beautiful church said to be the oldest black Catholic Church in the United States. The concert was fun and beautiful, but was overshadowed by the beauty and history of St. Augustine itself.

Plenty of history to take in. I recommend trying to get a guide to give you a tour and let you in on a little of the history.

On a very wet Sunday morning we went to St. Augustines to hear the choir, but we got so much more. Having read reviews on this forum, we got there early to make sure we got a seat. Maybe the rain kept people away, but the church was only about a quarter full. The first thing Rev Mulenga did was...


More  



The church is beautiful and the service moving. Wonderful choir and energetic priest who gave a sermon with the theme "Be a Christian". After mass we enjoyed looking round the church and then we asked where to get breakfast and were directed a few blocks to Buffa's where we had a splendid breakfast with a five or six piece jazz...


More  



This lovely, welcoming parish church features great music in a lovely older venue. The homily was awesome, and we enjoyed the service very much. The hospitality of the parishioners was especially memorable.

Having grown catholic, nowadays I'm not a religious person. I say this because we went looking for a gospel mass experience from a respectful point of view, not a usual sunday mass.
The music, sang from the heart, sure made its way to mine. All songs made the procedure longer than a usual mass (it ran maybe for an hour...


More  



Raised by free black parishoners in the Treme neighborhood this ancient church is showing it's age but plans are afoot to restoring it.

title: NOLA Tropical Winery, New Orleans
address: Outlet Collection at Riverwalk, 500 Port of New Orleans, Suite 144, New Orleans, LA 70130
review_list:
Walked in and LOVED the wine tastings! Delicious wines and a huge range of flavors from local vineyards! They also have awesome wine smoothies and to-go drinks too :)

Walked by---tasted---bought amazing wine from amazing Michelle! A must while visiting Nola! So many wine choices! Loved the sweet white wines and delicious smoothies too!

Every time I come to NOLA I make a point to visit the best wine store around! Free samples and great staff.. Make sure to try their amazing wine smoothies.. NOLA Hurricane Merlot is a must!

Best place in the area Lala was vary helpful best employee. Must stop here when in the area. Best wine I've had. Bought lots.

Michelle was great! The wine was delicious. We had several tasting of the wine and the smoothies. I was not disappointed. I will be stopping back before I leave to buy a few bottles.

The fruit wines are absolutely delicious and the wine smoothies are a must have! Michelle is amazing, so helpful and nice!

A must have. Had to buy mix to bring back home and even went on line to have some shipped. 1st wine smoothie ever and it was great.... Best smoothie I had in New Orleans period

In the river walk outlet mall, Michelle was amazing! We love this place, free wine tasting and then wine smoothies to go. It's amazing try it!

Soo good.. a must try! We've had it multiple times! Yummy . We keep coming back for more. Love the wine smoothies.

Michelle was awesome, bubbly and didn't miss a beat. Service personally all on tack and oh yeah your wines and smoothies were good too 😀

title: Beauregard-Keyes House, New Orleans
review_list:
Worth visiting - has great history. House plus collections and a garden. Well worth a tour. Across street from the historic church/nunnery so plan time to do both!

A tour of this house is a great introduction to the different architectural styles in the French Quarter and greater New Orleans. The tour packs a lot into a short amount of time.

A very short tour with only two people and the guide, it was more eerie than enjoyable. Of all the things I enjoyed in New Orleans, this is one I wish I had passed up on. Often I enjoy historical tours and architecture, but this was a lackluster experience.

This is a perfect example of what it was like for a Creole family of wealth to live like in the early 1800's before the Americans began arriving. It will show you the gentility of the period and how their society was of all importance to them and New Orleans as it developed to be a premier port city in...


More  



The guided tour of the house and grounds was excellent - the best I attended in New Orleans. The guide was informative and friendly - he is a great example of southern hospitality.

The tour in this house is modest and matter of fact but the spectacular comes from the visitor gaining understanding of how people lived 200 years ago. A must do for everyone who wants to learn how well to do people lived in the New Orleans of two centuries ago

Had the opportunity to visit this historic home, and had the luxury of a private tour. Very interesting history, and a truly beautiful home. Glad we made the decision to visit.

If you love to visit older homes with antiques, then this would be great. If you're like us who just want to visit things, it wasn't all that interesting.

I saw this home while on a self-guided tour hosted by the Friends of the Cabildo (FOC) and was delighted. It's a beautiful home with period furniture and decorations. We were fortunate to have been guided by a very knowledgeable lady in period dress.

This house is across from the old Ursuline Convent. Our guide was very knowledgeable about the house and residents. He encourage my daughter to play the 18th century piano.
Very enjoyable couple of hours

title: Harrah's Casino New Orleans, New Orleans
review_list:
Need to pay off I play 6,000 and didn't win nothing but 15x2 and everytime I came but a can play 6,000 at another casino on the same game in win $700 n up.

Only had a little time to spend there but it was easy in and out with valet parking. Only complaint I would have is that there was no place to put a drink down at the machine I played.

This Casino is big and beautiful. It is a smoke free casino which is great. Smells great inside. It is really beautiful with plenty of machines and tables. Aslo alot of food options there too.

I recommend anyone looking for great food and verity gaming! I always play the tables but I can enjoy the atmosphere this casino gives me so much hospitality and enjoyment ! I love Harrahs!

Been several times this was my least favorite time, staff wasn't very friendly, games weren't really fun or available, prices of tables changed constantly.

Great place to visit. I always enjoy myself. Free drinks and a chance to win some money. Nothing wrong with that in my books.

We went late at night and had an enjoyable time. The facility was clean and the atmosphere was exciting. It does take a while for the staff to bring you your beverages, so when you order something be prepared to sit there for a while.

a fun visit. walked around for a bit just to see what was going on. Poker, Black Jack, Roulette, craps and slots. There are also restaurants if you get hungry. My wife played the slots and enjoyed the free drinks. We didn't stay long, but had a good time.

We had lunch at McAliste'rs Deli in Harrah's. It was about what you would expect, but not on a par with the free standing McAlisters. Sandwiches were ok.

few people in the place on a weekend afternoon - should have told us something...almost no service personnel...seems like an afterthought in NOLA...much better odds in Vegas...would not return.

title: Old River Road Plantation Adventure, New Orleans
address: 2041 Canal Street, New Orleans la, New Orleans, LA 70112
review_list:
We went on the Old Oak and Evergreen tour in February with Richard as our guide. Although we wished we had chosen the Laura Plantation, it was overall a great day! Richard was kind and VERY knowledgeable, and he clearly loved talking about the history of the area. The tour of Oak Alley was wonderful and informative, although we would...


More  



Definitely worth doing for all history, architecture & curiosity buffs. Each is an experience that cannot be duplicated.

We had originally planned to take this tour with Isabelle Tours but their reluctance to commit until they had a certain number of guests scared us off and we found this company instead. We were picked up exactly where they said we would be at the right time and so began a long day of plantations and swamps.
The bus...


More  



We booked the Evergreen/Oak Alley plantation tour and the swamp tour before leaving on our trip. The cost was approx. $350 for three of us. The night before our tour the company confirmed the trip with us and then picked us up at the hotel the next morning around 7:30a.m. Our tour driver was wonderful! He was very full of...


More  



Each one is unique and has its own architecture and style as well as its particular history,but all are fascinating. Tours are possible in many houses and gardens and some have restaurants and rooms to rent. You can't understand the South unless you see how they lived and worked before the War between the States.

This was one of my highlights when we visited NOLA. Our tour guide, Jacques, picked us up promptly at our hotel. There was only a total of 8 of us taking the tour this day and it was wonderful! Jacques was very knowledgeable, and shared information continuously. There was never a lack of information. He welcomed questions and seemed to...


More  



I selected this tour company because of the opportunity to get off the beaten path, take a more scenic drive, and be in a smaller group. We did the two plantation and swamp tour package and very glad we did. Our tour bus driver gave an excellent narrative of what we would see, the history of the area, his personal...


More  



Our guide, Richard was the best. He shared so much information with you that you felt that you were a real part of the plantation experience and what it has meant to the development of the area and what it continues to mean. Oak Alley is one offering that is not to be missed. You could really spend a day...


More  



We toured with Old River Road To the plantations, Oak Alley, The San Francisco and then the swamp tour. The lunch provided was great. Our guide Jacques was great!

We did the Oak Alley and Laura Plantations and swamp tour. We had excellent customer service and felt taken care of during our tours. Our tour guide was very prompt. He shared a lot of history with us to and from the plantations.
Both plantations were worth visiting. They are both very different and give a good overview of what...


More

title: Canal Street / Algiers Ferry, New Orleans
review_list:
Loved to sit casually outdoors and enjoy coffee & local pastries of the area. More shops to saunter through for a distance to get to the end. Souvenirs.

Wonderful, relaxing 20 minute ride from Canal Street to Algiers. After a wander, back on the ferry to return - great value at $2 each way!

So convenient to get over to Algiers Point with several bars and quiet neighborhoods, The boat ride is fun and a change of pace, about 8 minutes from shore to shore. Biking path on banks above the river, you can take your bikes across on ferry. Runs every 15 minutes, on the quarter after and quarter to the hour on...


More  



Great way to see the river and get over to Algiers. Ferry is famous from the film Deja Vu. However, this is a working ferry but has the advance of crossing the river quickly and cheaply giving you great river views

The Canal St to Algiers Pt ferry is a family tradition for us, dating back into the 90's. Once upon a time, you could drive your car onto it and avoid bridge traffic. Now it's a great way to get to the CBD or French Quarter while still on foot. Or if your in the city, hop on over to...


More  



Seems like the time we got on it was time to get off. Very short ride. Nice if you want a view of New Orleans from the water. Lots of stairs to go up and down. (my foot is in a walking cast) It's just a few $$ to ride the ferry.

Our guidebook suggested that we take the Algiers Ferry across the mighty Mississippi for a great view of the nighttime NOLA skyline. It is a beautiful, beautiful sight. Well worth the quick trip and friendly places in Algiers to boot. Just lovely.

We rode this Ferry each day we were there because we stayed on the Algiers side of the river so it was very convenient for us. The cost to ride is $2 per person each way. the ferry has different schedules based on the day but usually runs about every 15 to 30 minutes. It is a great way to...


More  



The Ferry is $2/per passenger, each way. You can go ahead and purchase your return tickets upon purchasing the original way. The ferry is clean. The journey is short. It gets a little packed during peak times.

If you don't have a lot of time, I wouldn't take the Algiers ferry over. Not much to see once you get to this very residential area.

title: Hermann-Grima House, New Orleans
address: 820 St Louis Street, New Orleans, LA 70112
review_list:
Great for a look but just like any young people's hangout in any major city-peep shows, drunken youths and good buskers-a great place to walk through and keep walking

What a fascinating look into 1800s New Orleans! The Hermann-Grima house has been beautifully preserved and restored with period decoration and furnishing, a lovely courtyard, slave quarters, and the last surviving stables in the city. Our tour guide, Ellie, gave a detailed account of the families that lived there, the architecture of the house, and the historical context. She did...


More  



Everyone heads to Bourbon Street when they get to NOLA, mostly for the experience I believe. It is an amazing sideshow of humanity with a number of really good restaurants and bars on the street. Very quiet in the daytime, and this may be the best time to grab a bite to eat, or even a quick drink. In the...


More  



This is definitely a tour to take whether you are local or just visiting. Wonderful staff and well kept Museum.

Being inside the residence, you will get a true feeling of what life would have been like back in the early 1800's. It is a picture of wealth and refinement during a period that can only be appreciated through being in the home and enjoying all it has to offer. You shouldn't miss a visit to this living history.

We learn a lot about the way families lived in the early years of New Orleans. The docents were well informed.

We wanted to see a typical historic house in New Orleans and this one certainly had the potential to have its interesting history revealed. But the tour guide who showed us round rattled everything off in record-speed time and we were back outside in 35 minutes. She asked for questions in each room and every time we asked one, we...

We were unable to tour the inside due to it is privately owned but going on the ghost tour and hearing the history of the home and the owners that had experiences from it . Im just tempted to get a view of the inside of it.

This inexpensive tour was surprisingly informative and interesting. Our tour guide, a student herself, was friendly and personable. I learned several things about American and French architecture that I hadn't known before.

title: Bourbon Street, New Orleans
review_list:
What a electric place to visit!! The food is amazing and you have to find the food truck for an New Orleans Hot Dog.....

A melting pot of smells and people. Bourbon street is better if you are a little tipsy! Something for everyone. Avoid protein spills and horse dung. Good restaurants. On street over, Royale offers window shopping in expensive antique shops

this street is full of life, however not suitable for young children, there is music, of all kinds, bars are open you can go in and out listen to a wide selection of music for all ages, there is no cover charge, which is great, if you're a night owl this place is for you

The word quirky had to be first used re Bourbon St. Yes there are great restaurants (mostly on the adjacent side streets), and non-stop dance clubs, but definitely an Adults Only" theme along Bourbon. Families need to detour all that sleeze. Ranked average only due to the proximity of great restaurants.

I do NOT recommend bringing your kids here at all. It is very inappropriate. And whatever you do, DON'T go at night. It is filthy too.

I simply don't understand why anyone would actively seek this place out except to take an initial walk through the street to gawk at its awfulness. Avoid at all costs..

Even if you like to party, you have to be at the level of enjoying smelly filthy disgusting environment. Yes, it is famous. Go to a corner and have your photo taken with a street sign and be done. I made the mistake of thinking taking my teen during day time would be okay just so he could say he's...

we had a great time walking around and people watching. Lots of shops to look at and food joints. The old buildings are fun to look at and snap pictures of.

I was on Bourbon Street the morning of Mardi Gras and found the vibe to be really awesome. That being said, I think I would keep super young kids off this particular street. As an adult, you're able to take everything in, understand what's going on around you, and enjoy the culture and bars in the area. It really wasn't...


More  



Bourbon street is definitely a PARTY street. As much as I love to party and have a good time this was on another level. People are so intoxicated that they forget they have legs! People are urinating left and right it's kinda gross. However, the venues are definitely a lot of fun, they have live music and lots of dancing!

title: Frenchmen Art Market, New Orleans
review_list:
So, we thought this place was closed. Then about 7pm we walked by again, and it was opening. Lot's of handmade arts and crafts.

A great place on Frenchman street to take a break from the music and drinking. We were there three nights in a row. Each night had some of the same artists but also Different too. Some very unique things there to add to your decor.

While walking down Frenchmen Street, we saw beautiful white lights strung from one end of an open air market to the other brightening up the market full of people browsing and shopping. Vendors sell painted art, sculptures, quality jewelry, various parfums and more. I highly recommend the vendor Philip on St. Charles as he has a number of pleasant fragrances...

This is a cute, fun place to find homemade goods.
