There were a lot of unique goods there made by local artists. This is a good place to go...


More  



Don't go out of your way for this. I made a point of going here and really wanted to like it. It is all local art and some of it is good but most of it is just average. It's a nice little spot, off Frenchman Street, well lighted and there's nice seating available. It's only open at night and...


More  



I have never visited New Orleans and not stopped into Frenchmen Art. I always enjoy to see what they have received since the last visit

If you collect the kind of stuff sold at craft fairs, the Frenchmen Art Market is for you. Since I have no appetite for this kind of stuff, I would rate this just average. I'm not good at distinguishing good stuff from bad.

Fun place to cruise around and look at local art. Buy something! Shop local! It had something for everyone. Jewelry, paintings, clothing...there are places to sit and watch the crowd or for a photo opp.

A really beautiful spot on a clear evening. There was photography, painting, t-shirts, glass, and so many others.
A really great spot to browse in between dinner and music.

Great collection of local art. Lots of jewelry. Even had clothing and larger art pieces and a group of performers. The artists were really nice and eager to talk about their craft. One of my favorite things I did this trip.

title: The Spotted Cat Music Club, New Orleans
review_list:
Nice music, fun, not so jazz but good. When we went there, there was a cool band playing and singing some Latin music. Had a great time, would recommend it. Good atmosphere

Great New Orleans Jazz. The scene rocks and is so much fun. We heard Kristina Morales and her group. They were terrific. Two more musicians dropped by and joined
them and they were outstanding also. This place is not to be missed in New Orleans.

Tiny club with absolutely fantastic music. We didn't go in the night there was a cover, but went two other nights. Not many seats, but we did get front row seats for a set on Sunday night. Amazed by the jazz by each group there. Worth the tight fit of the club.

Visited this place one week before Mardi Gras. It is small and few seats are available, but the quality of the jazz more than compensate for that. There was no mandatory cover, but it would easily be worth the five buck they sometimes charge. If you like jazz I can't recommend enough.

We came here about 10pm and it was packed. It was standing room only. There was a five dollar cover charge. The music was wonderful. A lot of the old style jazz was played. We wish there would have been seating. We would have stayed longer. May try and come back when it is not so busy.

We stopped in after the parade and were charged $5 cover. After squeezing in, there was no where to sit and barely anywhere to stand (shoulder to shoulder). But they kept letting people in. They could use a lot more room for all the hype. Very uncomfortable experience.

Small intimate area: good drinks and saw/listened 2 great jazz for hours. Everyone has a good seat and very friendly employees and customers.

My husband and i were in town for Mardis Gras. We had to see Davis and visit this amazing venue. So glad we did. I was in heaven. Thanks Spotted Cat and Davis. Bucket list tick.

Worth stopping by to listen to good music and enjoy a beer. Unfortunately, it is very small and gets super crowded.

This is a great spot to hear new music and enjoy local beers. Not for the faint of heart, but if you've got the feeling, this is the place to be. A truly NOLA music experience and place.

title: Lafitte's Blacksmith Shop Bar, New Orleans
review_list:
This bar was one of our stop's during a ghost tour. It is supposedly one of the oldest continuously operating bars in the country, but all I can say is that it is a great building, and their bathroom works!

We love this little crowded bar. It is considered the oldest structure where a bar is located in the US. At the end of Bourbon Street, although not in the middle of the hub bub, it is always still crowded and fun. Do watch for pickpockets and thieves though - someone picked up a tourist's purse while we were there...


More  



This is a neat bar! The "purple koolaid" (what is taste like) will sneak up on you before you know it. Our first time here we were told only drink one & didn't listen...second one will kick your tail.

This is a great historic location/bar. They make the best Hurricane in town, just be careful because they sneak up on you. They only use candlelight at the tables for a more authentic feel. Can't wait to go back.

We loved the history here. The drinks are fantastics. The best Hurricane in the city. We made a daily trip there.

No blacksmith, Lafitte was a hunted pirate, - or a privateer, if you credit the warrant the Spanish issued, - paperwork makes all the difference. Get historical place. Their Hurricanes are the best. They make theirs with real juice. Fun place during Mardi Gras. My only complaint is they would not serve water.

We read about this establishment and knew we had to make a stop here. What a cool place. Loved the fireplace in the middle of the room and the old feeling. We chatted with a local who gave us several NOLA pointers. It's a must see while visiting the city.

Spent Mardi Gras here dancing in the street! An excellent if grungy bar with a great atmosphere. Filled with locals and tourists. Never saw a band but apparently they regularly have live music.

title: Royal Street, New Orleans
review_list:
Our group of 6 friends visited most of the antique shops and were very impressed with the quality and displays. Highly recommend the shops as well as the art stores, all are worthy of a leisurely visit.

We wandered down Royal several times during our time and were thrilled by the high quality and variety of street musicians. We heard everything from a Bach violin partita to traditional Dixie Land and Delta blues. It's great.

I loved this street!! Tons of awesome shops/restaurants, beautiful galleries, and excellent street musicians!!

Royal street is really cool. Alot of really great shops to visit. A good time to visit here is late morning and early afternoon. They have the street blocked off to traffic and there are a lot of street performers here. If their good, tip em a few bucks, some are really worth the show.

I love Royal Street! There is so much history, architecture, and great antique shops. On the weekends there are 3-4 entertainers per block. It's more peaceful and nice than Bourbon Street.

Most houses and shops on this street, including French and Spanish colonial styles, are kept in the best of shape and are permanently dressed up for festivities, with purple, green and gold predominating. Shop windows are fascinating and ever changing, and give a look into the values of the areas artisans and artists.

Offerings that would be coveted display items in a museum, the many antique houses (much too elegant to call shops) can save you a trip to the London Silver Vaults, or similar venues. Exquisite is only one of superlatives to be used in these locations. If your castle is yearning for that special adornment, you can, most certainly, find it...

This place has some cool features like architecture and street performers. It usually isn't very crowded.

Royal Street is known for its shops and high end antiques & art. A fantastic street to stroll around on, browse in the shops and spend a morning or afternoon on!! The shops are endless and everyone is different & unique.

Wow, what a beautiful street to walk down. This was the street my hotel was on and i was so impressed. Thinking the best was yet to come after i walk down royal street. title: Natchez Steamboat Cruise, New Orleans
review_list:
When you think of New Orleans, you probably think of huge paddlewheelers navigating the mighty river. Unfortunately, this is the last true steamship in town, and it offers up a great tour of it's engine room, the river, and the city. The guided tour tells you a ton of history, and the onboard buffet is amazing!

If you are visiting New Orleans you Must do the Natchez boat cruise with option for lunch or Dinner
Also if you love behind the Seen tours the Steam Engine room tour is Brillient
This is a self guided when the boat is moving down the river and you can speak to the Chief Engineer whilst he is working

The steamboat Natchez is a great experience. The man who narrates up the Mississippi is very knowledgeable of the area and has been on the boat since it started. There are two bars and a nice gift shop as well. The lunch was just ok. No real variety.

Thoroughly enjoyed the 2 hour cruise on a perfect day with a gracious crew. Lively jazz from the Steamboat Stompers topped it off.

Remember Huckleberry Finn and the Mississippi? Well the Natchez is the real McCoy.

review_list:

This is the worlds longest single stretch bridge spanning more than 22 miles. Except for the distant Man made building that are visible from either end , you get a feeling of driving over sea.
It is astonishingly easy to drive on the two lane highway. There are options to turn around and get back in case you decided to...


More  



On our drive to New Orleans from Ontario Canada we planned to take a small detour so we could travel on the Lake Pontchartrain Causeway. It cost $3 and it was worth it. I felt safe driving the bridge. As you get closer to New Orleans you see the skyline. Very nice view and worth the small detour.

Just loved crossing Lake Ponchartrain on the causeway - said to be one of the longest bridges in the world, if not the longest. The thing I enjoyed the most was being the middle of the bridge and not being able to see land in any direction - and for a distance of some miles. That was fun.

Lake Pontchartrain is huge and to understand just how huge it's worth driving the length of the Lake Pontchartrain Bridge or causeway. Guinness says that at 24 miles it is the longest continuous bridge in the world. For 7 or 8 miles of its length one cannot see either shore.

For the past two visits to New Orleans my wife and I have taken a walk along the south shore of Lake Pontchartrain (where Canal St. hits the lake, east of the restaurant Landry's). This is always head-clearing and restful. Also, you can get an idea of why hurricanes (the storms, not the drinks) are a cause for concern in...


More  



Found out we wanted to drive over world longest bridge. Amazing.. But look up for the police... they stood everywhere on the bridge.. so dont overspeed.

title: Memorial Hall Confederate Civil War Museum, New Orleans
review_list:
Small museum focused on confederate war history. Was worth a quick visit and is in a beautiful brick building.

Having just visited Charleston SC and its civil war venues it was equally exciting to see the items and read the accounts posted here attesting to the war of Northern Aggression. So many one of a kind donations for exhibitions with good accounts of the people and the events.

This is a collection of flags, uniforms, guns, and pictures that are labeled with all information necessary if you don't want to know anything about the big picture concerning the most important event in the history of the United States of America.

Great history and informational displays through out and close to the National World War II Museum just one block away! This was built by Civil War veterans and became the trusted repository for many family heirlooms and portraits of Southern heroes. Especially noteworthy is the crown of thorns woven by the Pope at the time and given to Jefferson Davis when he was imprisoned after the war. It was the 150th anniversary of the building when I visited in early...


More  



This museum is right across the street from the WWII museum! It is really small and should take you less than an hour to go through it! The staff was AMAZING! title: Confederate Memorial Museum, New Orleans
address: 929 Camp St, At St. Joseph's, New Orleans, LA LA 70130
review_list:
Those who fail to study history are doomed to repeat it. As a student of history, I wanted to take my wife to this fine museum before the revisionists destroy it, as they are trying to remove all the monuments to the war all around the city. This gives you an idea of the men who fought, the women who...


More  



We walked here one of the weekend days we were in New Orleans, only to find that the place was closed. Very disappointed, as we were looking forward to visiting this museum!

The museum is quite small in comparison to its across the street neighbor - WWII museum. There is a short film and quite a few Confederate artifacts, plus a small gift shop.

For all the mayors feelings in this city about tearing down the statues and history of the confederates and civil war, I hope they leave this lovely little museum alone.
Tip - go straight to the back room and watch the short video first as it really helps to understand what the south had to endure.
What struck me was...


More  



We found the artifacts to be well preserved. It is important to remember that what has made us a great nation is the fact that when the wars are won we rebuild and mend. Rather than destroy the history and dignity of the people we who lost. Lee was a great general! The people who fought for the Confederacy were...


More  



Neat museum with Southern history and charm. Loved the fact that it is the South's oldest museum. If you want to see the beautiful war memorials hurry because the city is hell bent on tearing them down. They are very close to this little gem.

Small museum with real life applications. You realize this was not so long ago when the last confederate died in the 1940's.
An interesting take on life in the south and particularly NOLA
Well worth the $8 entrance fee

I think they presented the exhibits in a reasonably fair way, but you have to remember they aren't honoring saints here. Lots of interesting objects, nice little gift shop. It's sort of across the street from the National WW2 museum.

In addition to the wonderful architecture, the exhibits are most interesting. Next to Ogden Museum and WW2 Museum, so we visited all three on a rainy day. Plenty of parking.

The museum is small with a $8.00 admittance for adults. My wife and I travelled the civil war trail, called the 'Hallowed Ground' which held many museums. In comparison I felt disappointed with this museums limited artifacts. I was however, impressed with there authenticity. It is a short walk from the WWII exhibit across the street.

title: Voodoo Authentica, New Orleans
review_list:
Took a chance and my wife got a card reading .. the folks were nice and some interesting things were pointed out. Not sure if I'm a believer, but it was a nice shop to visit .. lots of trinkets, could be fun if you have a wild side.

There's a lot to see in the French quarter but Voodoo Authentica stands out, unique and wonderful. A slightly plain exterior it could appear a bit forbidding, inside it's very welcoming. This is of course a mixture of tourist attraction and, for some, a place of religious belief. Unless you're willing and open minded enough to respect this I'd stick...

Great little place was very happy with the reading got me some oils very pleasant environment saw a tour there but I was just there for the reading and oils .

Went on a Voodoo Walking tour to learn more about its history and this was one of the recommended places to step into afterwards.
The staff is friendly and helpful. You can see someone who reads cards - but you will need to make an appointment.

This shop really is an authentic voodoo shop. Even if you don't intend to buy voodoo supplies it has information cards everywhere about the meanings of different items. It was very interesting!
Must see place in the French Quarter!

This shop is run by a very nice man with purple? I think its purple hair. I only briefly saw him, but his shop keep was very sweet! They were helpful and the shop is chock full of anything from stones to books to candles to statues! It's awesome! They also make custom gris gris for people. So sweet!

There was a lot to look at in here and a lot that confused me. They had some of the normal kitchy stuff you can get at every shop in NOLA but they also had some genuine things you could buy. We walked out empty-handed but looked around for like 15 minutes. It's a tiny shop so it's worth taking...


More  



After taking a Voodoo tour through Free Tours by Foot, which I highly recommend, we were led here to check out the shop. The guide dispelled a lot of the misconceptions about voodoo and I have a whole new respect for the practice. He also explained what a lot of the rituals mean and what is behind things like gris...


More  



Cool spot to pop in. It's a bit crowded and overpriced, however I still splurged on a cat dio de los muertos trinket for $25.

This isn't like most of the tourist-type voodoo shops you find around the Quarter. This is actually a shop for voodoo practitioners to buy the supplies they need for their craft. I found it to be very enlightening to hear a less Hollywood explanation of voodoo, and was very intrigued by the jars and jars of herbs and such in...


More

title: Tulane University, New Orleans
address: 6823 St Charles Ave, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
We took a stroll around the campus to break away from the hustle and bustle of the French Quarter. It was carnival time and they had a tree covered in Mardi Gras beads.

Just walking the campus grounds with its ancient trees is a sight to be enjoyed. It's always a pleasure to see so many young people busy between classes,talking and laughing with friends and at the same time preparing seriously for the future.

Catch the streetcar and get off at the front of campus for a nice walk down past Freret to the UC,where you can grab a bite to eat. Pretty awesome library, too.

Great program, an array of curricula, wonderful campus, great professors. If it wasn't for the many entitled students it would be perfect. I imagine that many of them are entitled because the tuition is so high.

A ride on the trolley to see St. Charles Street and the accompanying beautiful neighborhoods is not complete without walking on Tulane's beautiful campus. Be sure to see the tree that is covered with bead necklaces from the annual Mardi Gras. It shows that fun is not far away at any time at Tulane.

The Campus is nice and the trip all the way down St. Charles on the Street Car is $1.25 one way. There are places to eat at end of car turn around... The Campus is very nice and is right across the street from Auduban park.

take the st Charles streetcar and get off and just walk around. near Xavier and also by Audubon park

Beautiful campus, conveniently located. We visited with a prospective student, so we took the official tour.

A sybaritic setting next to Audubon Park and Loyola University, in the Garden District of New Orleans. Lovely buildings in a park like setting. It's an easy and inexpensive RTA streetcar ride from the French Quarter.

What an amazing place. Minutes from the French Quarter....on St Charles Street among stunning home....across from Audubon Park...the camps is so pretty with beautiful old building and lots of shady trees....

title: Ernest N. Morial Convention Center, New Orleans

review_list:
This large convention center is well located near many restaurants and other activities. First of all, find out which end of the convention center your conference is in and take the bus, the trolley or uber to that end. If you think you are going to get coffee when you get here, think again. There is a Starbucks, but the line is usually at least 30 people long (sometimes 200!). There were only...


More  



This place is HUGE. It goes on and on. Very nice place to check out. Right on the water front and close to everthing.

This convention center is very big and it can accommodate the really big shows. But the best part is that the city of New Orleans has provided a vibrant and exciting area around the center and it's hotels for the participants. There are well known restaurants right across the street, and the newly spruced up Julia St. area is right...


More  



Attended the 2016 American Meteorological Society Meeting here. The Convention space allowed for small to large meeting areas and plenty of common areas to bump into colleagues. Wish there were more seating options in the lobbies and hallways.

If you are attending a convention there, and they try to sell you an alligator sausage po boy, BUY IT. Plop yourself in one of those comfy chairs in the lobby and watch the traffic roll by as you eat. Good stuff!

4th year and 1 of the best ever. They do their best to accommodate the huge amount of people that descend on this annual event. Plenty of security and personal to handle this event.

I was in New Orleans on business for a week when I spent most of the daytime hours at this convention center. It is in an accessible area and has a pretty good floor plan. More  



the staffers at this facility were extremely nice and helpful, going over & beyond each time i needed assistance.

Attended a big convention that used most of the convention center. Comfortable shoes are a must. You can get a fair amount of walking in going from meeting to meeting. Was disappointed with the food options at 8 am but that got better around lunch in the center.

title: Old Ursuline Convent, New Orleans
address: 1112 Chartres St, At Ursuline, New Orleans, LA

The history of the Catholic orphanage here combined with access to St. Mary's Cathedral is a moving experience.

This oldest building in New Orleans provides a great overview of how the sisters of the Ursuline Convent did help with education and care for the less fortunate in the early years of New Orleans. The story of the two miracles and the large number of people that walked those hallways that got recognized by the church during and after...

Go through here and capture the rich spiritual history of America. Through this place and history you will get to know and understand how God helped make this country great. You will see old structures and get the stories of those who built them and worked in them and worked for the people of this area.
If you love beautiful...

My husband and I passed the convent several times while visiting New Orleans and thought it was just another convent. Were we wrong! It's the oldest building in the lower Mississippi River area. More  



This tour was very interesting with the religious aspects of the convent. There are no tour guides, but the ladies that were volunteering were a wealth of information. Without them stepping in an talking with us, the tour would not have been good. They had a wealth of information and made it come to life for us. Be sure to...

I think everyone should experience this quaint and historical place. It is run by really nice people who really want to tell you all kinds of factual stories of New Orleans. A final read and every room with antiques and pictures galore. Also check out the gift shop where you buy tickets that, it has some great jewelry and fun...

Enjoyed walking through the convent and gave a nice glimpse into the past. It's a self guided tour, but the docent was very knowledgeable and loved to share what she knew. The chapel is beautiful.

There is a lot of history in this facility since it was one of only two buildings that survived the fire that burnt New Orleans to the ground.

title: Old St. Patrick's Church, New Orleans
address: 724 Camp St., At Girod, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
What an experience. This church is absolutely beautiful. I do not normally go to a service there, but this last time I did and it was so wonderful.

it is so beautiful and has a long history and way more ornate then st. louis church and you go across the street for on of the best drinks in the city you cannot miss this church if that is what you are into go to mass there

This is a beautiful old church that has been well cared for. Easy walk to it from the convention center area.
Check out my pictures and throw me a thumbs up please.

St Patrick's Church is the oldest parish church outside of the French Quarter. It is absolutely stunning and worth a visit.

Attended mass and did a photo tour at separate time. Stunning. Very moving for mass. Pastor gives a good sermon

Attended Mass here in December and was just amazed at how beautiful this church is. Build in the early 19th Century, it was built about a generation after the Louisiana Purchase, and a generation before the Civil War, so these pews have seen good times and very bad times. There is a lot to take in architecturally that is hard...


More  



Loved the history in this church. The murals were beautiful, the floors, that are marble have areas that are worn from years of use.

A beautiful church, hidden away in New Orleans.
I had the wonderful opportunity to attend a Latin Rite Mass here one Sunday, The Mass was wonderful, the chant was beyond compare, and the church is STUNNING.
Even if you are not Catholic, the architecture and paintings are a wonder to behold.
Truly a treasure.

Old St. Patrick's was a beautiful surprise on an early October Sunday morning. The church is beautiful inside and the choir and music only added to the experience . The entire mass was said and sung in Latin, something we had not experienced for many years. It was not only a throwback in time for us but an uplifting delight...

The building is a beautiful place with ancient artifacts. Definitely worth seeing, especially if you love church architecture.

title: Woldenberg Riverfront Park, New Orleans

We found Woldenberg Riverfront Park a great place to get away from all the activity in the French quarter. The park has lots of areas for picnics and plenty of benches for watching the river flow by.

This one of the few places in New Orleans that you can get up close to the Mississippi River and the ships that sail on her. There is art to view, boats to watch and calm to be found. It is very clean and well maintained. A nice way to walk between French Market and Canal street.

this park extends from the aquarium to the old jax brewery near the square in the french quarter. it runs right along the mississippi river and is a flat easy stroll. you can see the big ships moving along the river or look back and have views of the city and french quarter. on weekends it is a gathering spot...

The riverboat plays cool music at like 5:30 every night. The Mississippi is wide and beautiful, barges roll along continually. What a magnificent riverfront! Every evening we would relax on the benches overlooking the Mississippi watching the ships glide down the river and the people jog and walk by. Simply beautiful, and full marks to the city of New Orleans for constructing and maintaining such a beautiful extent of property.

title: Louisiana Children's Museum, New Orleans
review_list:
I took my 3 1/2 year old grandson to this Museum along with his mom, dad and aunt.
I am not sure who had the most fun, but it was awesome. We all had a great time. Lost of interactive activities for people of all ages. My grandson loved the market! I highly recommend this venue!

The Children's Museum is a great place for kids, with lots of hands on activities. It's activities range from simple machines, to art and architecture with areas for exercise and reading and lots more. On a rainy day this place is a wonderful option.

This is a great rainy day or hot day, indoor activity. Very walkable location just outside the French Quarter. Two floors filled with activities with a separate toddler area. Good for kids 10 and younger. Something I had not seen before was the area with speed measurements of thrown baseballs and footballs plus the air hockey table to teach angles.

In town visiting my grandson (and his folks, of course) and wanted to find something different to do. They live in the Warehouse district so the location was perfect. I took my chances and purchased tickets to check it out. He's only 13 months old but they told me, when I arrived, that there's an area upstairs for the little...


More  



It's great for kids and as a children's museum that should be the goal. There are two floors of fun, interactive exhibits, with some tied to the area while others would work anywhere (like the mini grocery store). It's the kind of place where after a few hours you have to coax your kids into leaving, so it will certainly...


More  



This museum prizes activities that foster children's creativity and spirit of adventure. We loved all of the settings that mimicked real life, such as a working grocery store, diner and cafe, and construction site. Our little one was thrilled. We will be sure to return!

Louisiana Children's Museum participates in the ASTC Travel Passport program, making it perfect for out-of-town tourists with kids. Lots of great hands-on exhibits. My kids loved it.

Our four year old had a good time. Similar to other musuems we have visited designed for kids, however it did have a strong local feel. She particularly enjoyed the mock grocery story and restaurant areas.

The museum is very education and hands on. Many areas to meet all ages of children. Parents have fun also.

title: Lafayette No. 1, New Orleans
review_list:
Our family enjoyed walking through here for 15 minutes and looking at the different graves. There are some uniquely inscribed graves to enjoy and it's free.

Beautiful and so interesting! Parked on a side street and walking around the ceremony. The age is remarkable on the crips and how whole families are buried together.

This is a lovely and historic cemetery in the Garden District. Definitely register for a tour either with Free Tours by Foot or the Save our Cemetery foundation. Well worth your time!

We got a cab from the french quarter to this cemetery rather than find a tour or anything. It was great and located in a really beautiful neighbourhood in the garden district. Be sure to walk around after and check out all of the interesting houses.

We arranged our tour through Save our Cemeteries, and were very pleased. The guide loves his work and introduced us to things we didn't know we didn't know, like all the different types of tombs. Not much shade for escape from sun and heat, but it only took about 1 hour.

We took the tour from the bus and this was a beautiful cemetery. We did not go alone because most reviews warn against doing that.

A great place to do a self guided tour. There are plenty of free tour guides available online that you can follow along on your phone if you're interested in some of the history, or you can just move from grave to grave and let the headstones and tombs do the talking. Don't miss it.

It truly is a beautiful piece of history but is falling apart and needs some extra love. We did not have a tour through the cemetery but it was a stop during our bike tour where we were able to get out and walk around. Beautiful marble and stone plots everywhere.

We love visiting old cemeteries, and I'm so glad we stopped at this one. As we entered, they were just starting a tour. I can't remember the name of the woman holding the tour, but it was only $5. Our tour guide for the Garden District walking tour knew lots of really fun information about this cemetary. It was very informative and interesting.

Saw the Lakers vs. Pelicans game here. Was a great experience that my boyfriend will never forget. Was very easy to get there with an Uber. Security is good as well.

This was a great venue. The sound, the atmosphere, the workers... All above expected. I'd love to attend another event or show here.

I have been to Smoothie King several times for concerts. This was my first basketball game and I had great seats. The food is typically good with a New Orleans flare. Overall it is well kept and clean. Great venue for sports and conerts

I've been to my share of stadiums after years of being a sports reporter in the Midwest and the Smoothie King Center compares favorably to many of the venues in which I've worked. I had never been to an NBA Stadium and this being my first it was great. I would recommend seeing a game here when you are in town.

We went there for the trans Siberian orchestra. Place was very clean not a bad seat in the house and the concert was awesome. Close parking and convenient restrooms and clean restrooms. Drinks were a little expensive but not too bad and expected. Going back in March for another concert and would love to see a basketball game in there.

Attended WWE Monday Night RAW here. Have to say this is one of the better arenas I have visited. Was a decent size, not too big nor small. The seats were very comfortable. Seems like a great place. I attended a concert here with friends. It was a nice big facility. I would definitely return for another event here at this location.

title: Lafayette Square, New Orleans

review_list:
We were on a bus tour and we had the opportunity to drive by this park. It is beautiful to see and it would have been fun to have walked throughout it. It was rainy that day however, so we just enjoyed driving by it.

This attractive little park is a nice place to stop for a quick recharge.
We stopped there walking back from the WWII Museum and watched a movie scene being shot.
Nice place for a quick break - nice statues too. The big one in the middle is not Lafayette.

A nice break from the hive of humanity that is downtown New Orleans. It has a beautiful statue. Unfortunately, like many parks in the city, it's frequented by drunks and bums.

I always enjoy our visits to NOLA....Beautiful park and area for a stroll. Check out all the sites and enjoy all it has to offer

Cute little park in Lafayette Square that serves as a small observatory. A few structures, shrubbery & tiny walking path. Perfect for business people in the area to break away from the office and get a breath of fresh air.
~Christy

Nice artwork available around the park but also buskers and fortune tellers, sitting around, smoking cigarettes and talking to each other. About 15 minutes is enough time to see it all.

We tried all they had to offer.Gumbo,crawdads,Froglegs,Dalta catfish blackened,Gator,All real good.Sat out and watched the boats going up and down the Mississippi.Took a horse and buggie ride all over New Orleans tour was nice.

We were totally entertained during Blues & Bar BQ fest in the Sq. Nice area and restaurants to choose from, face in the direction the statues face and go left.

title: St. Roch Market, New Orleans

This place has all sorts of cuisines under one roof. You can't go wrong here and has a fantastic atmosphere that's warm and inviting.

NOLA hits it out of the park again in a beautifully restored 1875 building that is the launching pad for top chefs of all cuisines, from Asian to Cajun. This is an incubator of top cooking talent who will all someday have their own brick and mortar restaurants, if that's what they want.

Is New Orleans greT place to eat the crepes were outstanding and the service was great. Easy place to park and very clean

The oyster bar has great flavors

I visited the area on a Sunday morning circa 10am in a hire car with my family. I felt it was safe enough and drove around for nearly 30 minutes without incident or seeing anything threatening. Much of the devastated area has been cleared to vacant lots on the north side, however there are still many derelict abandoned brick houses...


More  



It is nice the see the neighborhood is coming back, but after ten tears I think a little too slowly.

It's very impressive to see what Katrina caused 10 years ago. We drove with the car in this neighborhood. We saw a lot of drama, but they are rebuilding this are fast. They are currently working hard on the roads and many new buildings are currently build.
Very impressive to see, but keep in mind that this neighborhood can be...


More  



I wanted to experience the 9th ward post -katrina , my experience was hope and vitality. It was so chilling to,read about the catastrophe. But was so wonderful to experience the come back .

If you have an hour, a car and a New Orleans street map or gps you should visit the Lower Ninth Ward. Twenty feet of water devastated this area destroying approx. 5000 homes. Ten years later maybe a couple of hundred houses have been rebuilt in about 10 contiguous blocks. Many of them were built by the Make It Right...

title: Warehouse District, New Orleans
review_list:
Our hotel was in this area so we had an opportunity to wander around a bit. We found lots of redevelopment and lots of established businesses - especially restaurants and hotels. The architecture is more industrial than the Quarter (of course, since this was - and still is - a business district) but it's still of a New Orleans style....


More  



We used to have a condo on Commerce in this area so I'm biased! It's the best place to stay, drink, and eat in New Orleans. This is where to "people" go. It has some of the best restaurants in the city and is much more laid back part of New Orleans. There are some amazing places to see that...


More  



My Favorite area of NOLA. Artsy, interesting, cool shops and restaurants. Not touristy but definitely must see area. Within walking distance of French Quarter.

I wasn't sure what to expect here, but it was nice. Lots of the buildings have been nicely renovated, and there are lots of shops and restaurants in them as well. Worth walking around and stopping for food!

While The Warehouse District is a bit of a hike from the French Quarter, it does have its own distinct personality. With scores of hotels, it is quieter and less frenetic than the French Quarter. Restaurants are on the mid-to-upscale range, and fairly expensive. There are tons of galleries to walk into, and it is a fun way to spend...


More  



By far the best place to stay, drink, and eat in New Orleans. Full of locals, by far the best restaurants in the city and the much quieter side of New Orleans. Not to be missed.

We stayed at the Renaissance Arts Hotel in the Warehouse District which is a few blocks from the French Quarter. The Warehouse District is a lot quieter than the French Quarter and is home to some nice bars, cafes and restaurants. The World War ll museum is also sited in this district of New Orleans. We especially liked the Legacy...


More  



It's an up and coming area full of bars, hotels and shops and more opens up all the time. It's close enough to the craziness of Bourbon, but far enough away for quiet love the converted warehouse hotels.

Loved the museums and the use of the old warehouses into new spaces. Grandchild really enjoyed the Children's Museum.

We spent some serious time here bouncing from museums to art galleries and breaking off in the area Bistros for a bit of an energy boost against walking in the southern heat. Loved the area and all the historic squares. Highly recommend for some New Orleans history and local creativity.

title: Gallier House, New Orleans

review_list:

Our guide was a young, enthusiastic architectural historian who herself is a native of New Orleans and of Creole origin. From this tour and our guide, we saw more than bricks, mortar and furniture in the house. We...


More  



This is a beautiful townhouse built on the eve of the Civil War and meticulously restored. The entry price ($15) is a bit steep, but it was worth it thanks to our excellent tour guide who was eloquent and extremely knowledgeable about the house and the era. He shared a lot of interesting information about the Gallier family and life...


More  



Our guide, Peter Dandridge, did an outstanding job of guiding us through Gallier House. We visited many older homes while in New Orleans and our while group agreed this was the best narrative we had ever experienced in a house tour. He knew detailed interesting information about the home that enriched our experience.

Forget Bourbon Street. Try the several historic homes in the French Quarter. This one had a great guide who knew every question we asked. He related this house to the other one ( Hermann-Grima) both operated by the Woman's Exchange. Do them both with this one second. You will see the differences in living arrangements, family life style, community traditions,...


More  



This is a "sister" house to the Hermann-Grimma House. That means that if you visit one, you get a discount on the other. We visited both and highly recommend both. The tour starts outside at this house where you get a brief lesson on wrought iron vs cast iron. Mr. Gallier was an architect, so there are some interesting touches...


More  



The Gallier House was one of the highlights of my recent visit to Nola. The house is beautiful and the tour was insightful. Our tour guide was knowledgable and answered all of our questions. The museum has excellent customer service was also extremely accommodating! Would recommend!

NO INSIDE PHOTOS. I was one of four on the tour, and the only one under 40. The home was wonderfully restored back to the 1850’s. They were able to get a manifest of the homes inventory from insurance records, and find pieces that matched. The tour was a little over an hour long. I found it highly entertaining to...


More  



This is a wonderfully restored historic home located in the French Quarter. The current furnishings are based on an inventory of the home's original furnishings. There is a 45 minute tour that begins on the hour. The cost of the tour is $15 per adult, but check for special half price offers. Our tour guide was quite knowledgeable and brought...


More  



The tour was about 45 minutes and quite good. Combined with the Herman grima house
it was a nice comparison. Is it a MUST-SEE, no, but if you have the time it is nice to roam around in the old houses.

This house can be visited by itself, or as a combo ticket with the Hermann-Grima Historic House.
The guided tour was well designed starting across the street from the mansion with info about its architecture style and how it was built.
The house was turned into a rental for a number of decades and does not retain as many of...


More

title: Chartres Street, New Orleans
review_list:
This a nice street to pick out little shops to visit. There are a ton of areas to shop, but this is another nice place to check out.

I'm rating this second to Royal and ahead of Bourbon for a good French Quarter experience. The crowds are more fluid than Royal (many are just heading to and from Jackson Square) and less rowdy than Bourbon. The history is here, too. Many cool buildings, interesting shops and popular restaurants.

To me every street in the quarter has great places to visit and see. Chartres has some wonderful shops... and there is always something to catch your eye in the windows.. And Food?? well its New Orleans there is great food on just about every corner.. Ask a local for their fav spot

After walking around the quarter we realized it was getting late, went into Snug Harbor for a burger, found the kitchen closed. Now what?... thank you Pedi-cab guys, especially Mag. She toted us to Chartres st. Had to drop off at the corner due to construction. She told us about this place called DAISY DUKES. Food finally. .. and it...


More  



Some good restaurants and shops. More low key than Bourbon and a whole lot less ghetto than Decatur. Make sure to visit the Chartes House for some great bbq shrimp! In October 2015, the entire 100 block (closest to canal) is being torn up and repaired. The road and some of the sidewalk is closed.

Some of the best restaurants and bars are on Chartres street. Great place to get off bourbon have some good drinks at the Chartres house then take in some of the book shops on the street.

Like most of the New Orleans this street has a great vibe and some great bars with live music. We were there for Mardi Gras and it was nice to escape from Bourbon Street. This still had all the buzz, but more upmarket than Bourbon Street.

Love to go to New Orleans. So many museums to see and places to eat. weekdays are not quite so crowded during the main part of the day.

A wonderful New Orleans street worth checking out. Has some cool shops and restaurants to see. Of course the architecture is very neat and varied. Walking down the street you come upon Jackson Square with its bustle. Or if you leave from Jackson Square it is a nice break from the crowds and you can get lost in the surroundings....


More  



Chatres is one of the French Quarter’s most important streets, not least because it is one of the four streets that frame Jackson Square, with St. Louis Cathedral, Cabildo ,and the Presbytere all fronting on Chatres. We walked enough of Chatres during our recent visit to appreciate that it has sections that are quite charming and not at all crowded...

I had seen ads for MS Rau in the Wall Street Journal and New York Times and was fascinated by the jewelry and silver shown so squeezed in a visit between meetings while in NOLA on business. What a place! Full of items that are not antiques just because they are old, but rather because they are the best items in their class. I was getting dizzy from all the Tiffany silver sets. I may not be able to afford much of it, but I was immensely impressed with their collections and staff expertise.
We went to...


More  



What an inventory, what a staff, what an experience! An hour wasn't enough, we were back a second day. No push - just the kind of people and store I hope to deal with again someday soon.
Visitors...


More  



One source says what seems to be an elegant "little" shop has over 30,000 sq ft in a warren of rooms that seem to go forever. This place is fascinating, enlightening, and free. And the staff are always courteous and welcoming, which is much appreciated by this sometimes footsore fan of history and things historical.
Want to see Admiral Lord...


More  



An article appeared on my news feed while in NOLA calling it one of the top 13 spooky things to do while visiting. There is a "hidden room" you can ask to see by tour. The room wasn't exactly spooky but the rare items left us in awe. They have some of the most beautiful items in their showroom as...


More  



Get off Bourbon Street and stroll down Royal Street with its wonderful shops. M.S. Rau's Antique shop is not to be missed. It's like walking through a history museum. The silver, china, jewelry, furniture, and many other items are gorgeous. The staff is friendly and helpful, even if it's obvious the customer is only browsing (which would be us). I've...


More  



We stopped in M.S. Rau Antiques while roaming Royal Street. It's deceptively small from the outside. Once inside there are many twists and turns. The merchandise for sale is of unbelievable quality and rarity. Gifts from the pope, large meteorites, an Enigma machine are just a few examples. The variety is astounding. The sales agents let you roam freely and...


More  



Walking into M.S. Rau Antiques, you'll feel like you've been transported back in time to different places and different cultures. The shop is a stunning array of artifacts from all over the world. Look closely in the cases and on all the shelves. You'll feel like you're in a museum of historic randomness. Really lovely place.

A wonderful place for collectors or to "window shop" if you aren't rich enough to be a collector. Some really beautiful and unusual items and the staff was very nice to us even though we were clearly "just browsing".

Lots of expensive things. But fun to go in and see. Always stop by just to look. Worth it. Jewelry is amazing. Don't pass up.

title: Canal Place, New Orleans
review_list:
Quiet mall with higher end stores. Movie theater and local gym on level three and small food court. One of the food courts places has great protein shakes. (Forget name). Outstanding! Anthropology, banana republic and lulu lemon also in this mall. I like shopping here, it's clean and just the right size.

Nothing beats the Shops at Canal Place, for fine goods and services. This is the upscale mall in the city, all rolled into one beautiful venue.
Check the hours; not open as late as you would expect.

Definitely recommend going to Canal Place to those who like high end shopping. Saks Fifth Avenue is the anchor store. Other stores include Armani, Tiffany's and Lululemon.

Beautiful mall inside but shops are for people who want to spend money on things that shouldn't cost that much and can be bought for much less other places. Associates inside Michael Kors are too high pressure and merchandise can be bought for less elsewhere.

the mall was / is pretty to look @ and walk through, though it did not warrant the feel i seek when visiting nola. the feel garnered there was ... "too expensive" for my consideration.

The volume was low and the were too many lights on. The wait staff continued to disrupt the movie. I will not be back to a movie that serves food.

We very much enjoyed the atmosphere at Canal Place. So many options of food and great place got some decent shopping. Definitely a good option to spend an evening.

This is just a mall with some expensive shops. Not really what you come to New Orleans for, but it's a nice place to kill some time if you need to.

The Banana republic had some great deals and a few other shops were ok but mostly items here for the super wealthy.

Visited Sept 2015 and saw The Gift ! Great movie and had the whole theatre to ourselves! Didn't like the concept of them bringing the popcorn to me and the food was really expensive. I think the place might have had more people in it if the snacks or food wasn't so expensive. Still enjoyed the movie and the theatre...


More

title: Storyland, New Orleans
review_list:
This was a small but cheap bit of fun for the kids. This particular area had different play areas based off of children's books. Kids can walk and enjoy the scenery. They got to explore a rocket, see models of the three houses the pigs built, see the shoe that the old lady lived in, etc. It didn't take long...


More  



We road the street car out here and enjoyed the walk through the park. Storyland is only $4/person. It was a fun play area for kids probably 8 and younger. Things to climb on and a couple of slides. Tree covered walkways throughout the area. Small so it only takes an hour or less to see everything. It does have...


More  



The kids loved the fast dragon slide and enjoyed climbing around on the different story book features. It held their attention for an hour.

Storyland itself isn't very big and can be gone through in about 30 mins. I wouldn't make a special trip to see it. The trees are beautiful and there's plenty of shade. The walkways are uneven and the little houses look a bit in disrepair. There are two slides (one wasn't working when we were there.) My daughter had a...


More  



Visited with our 4 year old who seemed quite happy at Storyland. Parents and grandparents couldn't quite overlook the fact that the park is falling in disrepair. Building are crumbling and everything needed a good scraping and a new coat of paint (or 2). This is a 15 min attraction.

Young children love this place! You can spend hours here letting little children run and play all over the story land area.

The good: love the trees! Cute premise in a run down way. Friendly attendant who helped us. We were the only ones here on a Friday afternoon. I don't know if it's just deserted or bc of all the construction. The amusement park was closed and there were barricades up surrounding Storyland. There was also construction in the Botanical Gardens...


More  



Old live oaks form a complete canopy over the rides and attractions in this park. Mostly for children, but adults will enjoy it as well. The continents oldest carousel is located here and is the highlight of the visit. Sit with a snowball and watch the kids play while you enjoy the natural scenery and all the sites.

$4 a pop for the adults, 18 month old child free, two hours of squeals and giggles... Priceless!
Great way to let a sprout run around and tire them out!

My 4.5 year old son had a blast running from one nursery rhyme character to the next. There are cute slides for the kids to go on too. It is definitely more geared for the under 5 age group though.

title: Southern Food and Beverage Museum, New Orleans
address: 1504 Oretha Castle Haley Boulevard, New Orleans, LA 70113
review_list:
What fun to visit a museum about food and especially that nutritional minefield - Southern Food.
Now in its new location the museum has room to spread out - they now have enough room for their displays and cooking classes. They also have interesting and fun special events scheduled.
The museum does their best work showing us the history of...


More  



Unique museum featuring southern states and their food histories. The tour gave a New Orleans historical perspective of alcohol, cocktails and hospitality. The food demonstration was a delicious lunch and educational experience that explained Creole versus Cajun, along with the historical influences on the food of New Orleans

It is hard to beat a museum dedicated to one of the things I absolutely love. Individual displays dedicated to the cuisine of each state of the American South. Needless to say, Louisiana gets a substantial exhibit, but since you will probably taste many of the items displayed and described here, you'll understand they probably deserve the space. The beverage...


More  



We rode the Charles Street streetcar here, then walked a couple of blocks north. The museum has moved from its spot on the river and expanded into a great open space. There are exhibits of 3D artifacts chronicling the culinary contributions of each Southern state, and a wall that traces the history of the American cocktail. We had read a...


More  



Fun and friendly place with displays from southern states, focused on their foods and drinks. Even fast food that originated in the South, like Popeyes. I learned about chicory and absinthe, which I've always been curious about. There's a cute bar and restaurant attached and a little gift shop. Cooking classes too, but I think only on Mondays. Teen daughter...


More  



Quite a little gem! Varied displays of all types of southern food, from rice, alcohol, BBQ, creative food photography, cookbooks, sugar cube city, well known area restaurant paraphernalia, past presidential table settings. Food samples are not a part of the museum, but a small restaurant is attached to the museum. There is an admittance fee for the museum. Cooking classes...


More  



My husband and I came for the cooking demonstration and museum tour. For $40/person, it was a great value. The dishes were yummy (tomato salad remoulade, jambalaya, bananas foster) and it was nice to also get a history lesson while it was cooked. The museum is small but interesting. We enjoyed the Popeyes exhibit because it's our favorite fast food....


More  



Thank you to all of SOFAB
Well done! Love the place and eager to visit the Library tomorrow.
Long over due
The sky is the limit

The museum itself left a lot to be desired with a professionally done cocktail exhibit, cheesy state by state tables with some typos, some really fascinating stuff like an exhibit on St Joseph's Altars and the "Katrina food cart" all scattered randomly around a big open space that was a ware house and a market in the past. A big...


More  



It's too bad that this museum isn't located closer to other tourist attractions, because it is so interesting! It is well worth the taxi or uber ride over. The cocktail portion has a lot of interesting artifacts and displays. Food is such a large part of southern culture, and this museum is full of fun facts and a welcoming, knowledgeable...

title: Anatolian Silver, New Orleans
address: 1235 N. Peters St, French Market, New Orleans, LA 70116
review_list:
I always go to the French Market when I visit NOLA. I try not to make eye contact with the jewelry booth owners because once you do they latch on to you and try to bargain when your just looking, Its very uncomfortable. But not this booth. Anatolian Silver was so nice, so polite. Let me look around with no...


More  



Wandering through historic French market came to this clean stall with gorgeous very well priced jewellery - Stirling silver. I bought for myself and many gifts as the price, variety and quality was the best in the market and they all came in lovely little gift bag. The vendor Hasan wasn't rude or pushy and he gave us some really...


More  



This jewelry shop located in the Historic French Market beats all for quality jewelry @ competitive prices. The selection varies from the traditional fleur de lys, to the modern NOLA water meter & come in pendants as well as earrings. He also carries crosses, and traditional type gifts. The selection and price cannot be beat.

Excellent variety of silver items suitable as gifts for my friends and young family members. Fairly priced and nice quality. Worth seeking out!

If you love New Orleans and looking for that perfect, not over-stated piece of jewelry, please stop in to Anatolian Silver. Today I purchased 2 pendants that come with chains, 2 charms and a pair of earrings. Less than $100. Since this trip to NOLA is extended, I will be going back for Christmas gifts. Don't be fooled by the...


More  



The best place to buy great quality silver jewelry. I wear mine daily and always want to purchase here. Highly recommended above any other vendor and the best prices!

While visiting family in New Orleans, I stopped at Anatolian Silver. My brother shops here for gifts for us and the quality and beauty are unsurpassed. I got the most beautiful silver earrings for a really reasonable price. Mr. Cicek was so helpful and knowledgeable and it was a wonderful shopping experience.

I shopped around a bit in the French Market and found the prices here at Anatolian Silver to be the best, plus Mr. Cicek is very friendly and nice to talk to. Ask him to show you a picture of his cat! I bought several pieces of silver jewelry and am very happy with my purchases.

Very pretty designs with high quality semi-precious stones and low prices. Have been a repeat customer for over ten years and will continue to shop whenever we visit N.O.

Mr. Cicek and his wife were friendly & extremely knowledgeable about their jewelry. Super patient and not pushy, Mr. Cicek allowed me to enjoy my shopping experience. Thank you for the beautiful earrings (I brought 6 pairs :-) and great conversation!!!!

title: Rosetree Blown Glass Studio, New Orleans
review_list:
The dear husband and I had a long weekend in NOLA and having been there several times we were searching for something a little different to see/do this time around.
Thanks to TA we opted to seek out the Rosetree Glass Studio. The shop had some very lovely pieces and we took home a large vase...a good value for the...


More  



From the ferry you arrive at the historic district of Algiers Point, where you'll walk buckled sidewalks (watch your step) to a midcentury movie theatre which has new life as a glass blowing studio. An introductory film in a comfortable seating area overlooks the kiln area where you can see artisans at work. Lamps, glasses, fan pulls and other artworks...


More  



We took the short ferry ride across the Mississippi to Algiers Point, walked through the historical section of homes to the gallery, where we were welcomed like family. We watched a video and three artisans blowing glass. Then we shopped the gallery of gorgeous glass where we were in awe of many beautiful works of art. The whole experience was...


More  



This was an excellent morning spent watching the glass blowers in action. prier to that we were sat down to watch a video of the art of glass blowing by the owner Mark Rosenbaum.
We then browsed the studio looking at the wonderful glassware.

This was an amazing night for all of us. I never thought I could make anything myself but with the guidance of Devon I actually made a glass flower. A true treasure. The studio is full of beautiful glass-blown vases, ornaments, flowers and too many other beautiful pieces to mention I can't wait to make another visit.

Thanks Mark! Our family girls night out was amazing. The Rosetree gang provided a great experience and quite an education! It was by far one of our best times together and making such beautiful flowers was a treat beyond expectation!! We can't wait to go back...all 14 of us! Anyone wanting a great time and lasting memories...This is the place...


More  



Stopped by the Rosetree Blown Glass studio and just loved my visit there. The owners are extremely friendly and willing to explain the process of how they make their beautiful art. I alway though blown glass was beautiful but now I have a deeper appreciation for this art. This is definitely a great stop while in New Orleans.

The works are very creative and most artistic. It's fun to see what can be created with glass. It is in a converted old movie theater and the owner received the first master degree that Tulane University gave in glassblowing.

A must stop if you are in Algiers Point. Great for special gifts or momentos of your time in New Orleans.

Visited New Orleans on a family vacation and did the class with my twelve year old. Owners were very nice and the woman who actually blew the glass with us was fantastic with my both of us. Algiers Point was lovely and the studio was pretty cool in an old art deco theater. Nice glass in the studio also. One...

title: The House of Dance and Feathers, New Orleans

So glad we visited this " museam" which we would never have known to do if not for the Ninth Ward bike tour we took. There is so much to see in this collection - infinitely detailed Mardi Gras Indian parade costumes, ossified wine bottles, collections of shoes from the Muses parade, photographs of different chiefs, elaborately feathered second-line umbrellas...and so much to learn from its host, the gracious Mr. Ronald Lewis, whose formidable knowledge of the neighborhood and its traditions bring the smallest element...

Ronald Lewis, the founder and keeper of The House of Dance and Feathers is an incredible storyteller, activist, and artist who guides you through histories of New Orleans. From the devastation, injustice, and community action resulting from Hurricane Katrina to a colorful and thoughtful explanation of Mardi Gras Indians, everything we learned enthralled and inspired us. His collection is breathtaking...

We were brought here on the excellent Lower 9th Rebirth bicycle tour run out of the Confederacy of Cruisers cycle shop.
Mr Lewis is a fascinating character with so much history and so many stories that he can totally captivate you for a long, long time. Yes the 'museum' is essentially an outbuilding in his yard piled high with artefacts...

It's really difficult to put into words just how cool this place is. Not only can you learn about the culture of the Mardi Gras Indians and African American Social Clubs, but you get to learn the history of the Lower Ninth community pre and post Katrina. Ronald has story upon story and is willing to share each and everyone....


More  



Well it was a teeny bit hard to find and a little bit out of the way deep in the 9th ward. The proprietor was an interesting character who has collected every article in there or had donations from personal friends.
His knowledge of New Orleans, black culture and native American interactions with black history in Louisiana was incredible. The...


More  



When visiting New Orleans, take a break from the typical Bourbon street dining and drinking activities and enjoy some real cultural Louisiana history and stories from one of the most amazing people I have ever met. His stories will fascinate you. His memorabilia from Mardi Gras ( The Second Line) parades will amaze you and his pictures and real life...


More  



This is basically one man's tribute to the endangered culture of the Mardi Gras" Indians" from the 9th ward. He gathered up many relics after the storm and put them into a "museum" in his backyard, which he runs with his two adorable granddaughters. The owner, Mr. Lewis, is himself part of the Mardi Gras Indian tradition going back many...

We were honored to be able to visit this national treasure of a museum in the backyard of Ronald Lewis. He has showcased the amazing heritage and culture of the Mardi Gras Indians through costumes, photos, books and more. Everything from parade throws, hand beaded costumes worn by the Indians to samples of the food and water provided to them...


More  



Ronald Lewis is the most engaging host and his collection of artifacts, as well as his stories and photos of his time with the Mardi Gras Indians is a fascinating piece of New Orleans history. There is no fee to enter, but donations are helpful!

title: Voodoo Spiritual Temple, New Orleans
review_list:
Go to a Real Vodoun Mambo like Sallie Ann Glassman at La Salvation Botanica.Always research first! Sallie Ann is one of the few legit Mambos in the US that many people fly in to see.

Visit Priestess Miriam. She is a wonderful, kind soul. Learn about New Orleans Voodoo in a safe, non-scary setting based on spirit. Definitely a different experience, but a NOLA experience worth doing. Ask to tour the temple, for a donation. Interesting, different, and on point.

I stopped by here upon suggestion from a local as well as some good reviews online. I was looking for an authentic voodoo/ root religion experience after learning a lot about it locally. Going in expecting to meet someone to share some thoughts with - ask questions to, we were greeted by a woman (not the priestess) sitting in the...


More  



My friend and I went expecting to learn more about voodoo but we were greatly disappointed. The space is set up more like a shop and there is a shrine where you can put your offerings. However, the whole time we were there NONE of the people who worked there bothered to come out to say hi or ask if...


More  



The whole time I visited, I honestly didn't know how to feel. Nothing gave me the creeps about the place, but I did think it was odd that a place with that much "spiritual" presence was so visible and open for people to by trinkets from. Nevertheless, I bought some decent incense from there and left a coin behind.

Enjoyed our visit here very much. Priestess Miriam was a delight to talk with and enjoyed her tour the temple which was like the most interesting museum I have ever seen. The shop had a variety of reasonable priced trinkets. Enjoyed the visit here so much especially just having conversation with Miss Miriam.

As a not religious person the visit was a very interesting experience. We knocked on the door and priestess Miriam invited us to her places. We entered the shop and were not sure if that was all. We almost were on our way out when we figured out that you have to cross the shop and the temple is is...


More  



We dropped in and went on...... a very enlightening experience with our host.
Man is she spiritual!... in a VOODOO way that was very heart felt and conveyed throughout our many DEEP conversations.
You can tell the moment you go in she is the real deal.

Met her and visited the Temple with Altars to Spirits where she does her African Bonecasting readings. Adjoining Culture Center which had a retail store with great authentic African handcraft items at a very reasonable price for touristsd on a budget. This is a one of a kind in the world must visit.

Very accurate. My visit here was approximately 8 yrs ago, it still resonates.

title: New Orleans - Hop On, Hop Off Tour, New Orleans
review_list:
We took the Hop On, Hop Off Tour this past week. It is a great way to get an overview of New Orleans. The guide was knowledgeable and fun and the tour route was excellent. Nice tour, well worth it. Very informative & entertaining. Tour went all around town and learned a lot of cool interesting facts about NOLA.

title: Prytania Theatre, New Orleans

Throughout the years of massive blockbusters requiring screens the size of battleships, sound systems with enough power to deafen neighbors, and IMAX 3D everything, Prytania has held its own. title: Lower 9th Ward Living Museum, New Orleans
review_list:
Why should you care about the Lower Ninth Ward? Find the answer in this humble museum. The four small and spare rooms document the long history of governmental and societal neglect of a marginalized population. Katrina was not the first assault. More  



This was our first stop in New Orleans. We were repeatedly cautioned to avoid the lower 9th, but we felt FAR safer there than on Bourbon Street during the afternoon. More  



One of the best museums I've seen. Clear descriptions, photos, film explaining the history of the Lower 9th Ward, the effects of Katrina and the disastrous effects of inaction and incompetence by federal and state government agencies.

Visited this museum during a recent visit to New Orleans. It was a transformational experience for me as I thought the perspective/voice of the residents were aptly depicted. More  



This is a must see in New Orleans. If you have time take a trip to see this very strong monument to the suffering of the Lower Ninth Ward. Put away any preconceived notions of blame and take in a grass roots memorial.

This living museum shows how people live from day to day, It's not full of treasures, but shows a life well lived, even it is to an extent materially deprived. Take a look, it's worth it.

More  



This is a tiny museum but don't let that fool you. We spent two hours mesmerized by the history, the personal stories and the policy/follow-through failures that led to the devastation of the Ninth Ward post Katrina. Go to this museum!!!!

The way the human beings living in this area have been treated by throughout history is a shameful disgrace. review_list:
This is not a furnished period home, but one of the oldest in the city open to the public. Not only is this a great find for architecture buffs, but it houses a display of Arts and Crafts Newcomb pottery. This makes for an interesting half hour or so.

This is a great example of French colonial architecture that existed prior to a fire that destroyed much of the city during the eighteenth century. title: Lee Circle, New Orleans

review_list:
Upon the news that this memorial,as well as others in New Orleans, doomed for removal by insane politicians,we made it a point while there to pay homage to General Lee and shoot a few photos in the morning fog. Last night we were kinda aware even more of its demise,seeing the spotlights around it weren't on. Sad to see this...


More  



Had to see the General and pay our respects. No one is maintaining the grounds. Graffiti everywhere. A hearty F' you to the mayor and city council.

Lee Circle will soon be gone. Don't wait. The city is destroying its history at an unprecedented pace. Lovely spot opening to St. Charles Ave.

This statue to General Lee is located near the start of St. Charles Avenue. If you board the streetcar heading towards the "Uptown" area of New Orleans, you will past right by it. It's been there for more than 100 years and from what we were told, the plaza use to be a haven for the many homeless in the...


More  



The New Orleans City Council just voted to remove this statue and rename the circle, so if you are currently visiting New Orleans, this is your ABSOLUTE LAST CHANCE to get a picture of the statue.
I've been visiting New Orleans for years and this was always a great place to congregate for Mardi Gras. It's too bad that will...


More  



Hard to get to and hard to see once you get there. Pretty under whelming but still a piece of history.

Sorry to be the first negative review. But this is just a round-about as you drive down to the CBD and the Quarter. Worse still, it's populated by bums and surrounded by convenience stores. Yes, Belocq is here as is the Circle Bar so don't rule it out entirely. But let's face it - if New Orleans wants to finally...


More  



This is a fabulous circle and statue of General Lee. So glad this is here to honor the Southern heritage! I hope they do not tear it down, as I have heard rumored.

A fourteen ft bronze statue of R.E. Lee stands above a ninety foot granite plinth that the current administration wants to take down. Preservation groups adamantly oppose this action. You'll have to wait and see what happens.

This statue is a part of the heart and soul of New Orleans and is well worth seeing. The trolley circles it and Robert E. Lee looks defiantly South. One of the great works of art in this city that is in danger of being destroyed because of political activism. While Lee has now become subject to social whims we...
