title: Fort Pike State Historic Site, New Orleans
address: 27100 Chef Menteur Highway, New Orleans, LA
review_list:
Tried to visit - but it was closed due to repairs needing to be done to the actual fort! Therefore cannot do 100 characters - will try to visit next time, when in the area!

When arrived at the site we noticed that the site was closed. Without any previous notice on the signs by the road, we traveled for nothing. We didn't manage to get a good sight of the fort. Very disappointing. Please try to inform your self by locals to see if it is already open before traveling to the Fort.

My husband and I were disappointment to see the Fort Pike was closed to the public. We went to several forts in Louisiana and discovered most were close and in need of repairs. Most of the old forts in Alabama and Florida are being maintained and cared for. We view Fort Pike from a short distance. We could see it...


More  



My family have visited this historic fort when i was a pre teen. We fished and crabbed in the waters around the fort. Now it is protected as a historic site. It now has picnic areas, restrooms, boat launch, parking and much more. Finding it is not easy just drive to Chef Menteur pass along hwy 90 also known as...


More  



Unfortunately, Ft. Pike is not open to the public until some time in 2016 - it was hit hard in a tropical storm a few years ago. *I did not visit in 2015* When I was there last, they sometimes have reenacts there cooking over an open fire and doing period demonstrations. There is a great view of the Rigolets....


More  



Was on the way to Pensacola from New Orleans when we passed this gem. My understanding is that they've closed it due to lack of funding, which is really a shame. The self-guided tour was a bit lacking, but we still enjoyed our visit a great deal.

A very nice, extremely well maintained historical monument. The old fort is fascinating for history buffs. The scenery is great for pictures, especially if you have your DSLR handy and a lot of imagination. This was a great little stop. We roamed around for about an hour. It would have been a nice picnic spot. Very nice clean rest rooms.

Drive past all the homes on stilts (risky you would think to build a house there but nice and remote) and you will find the fort. The fort never saw battles but Seminole Indians were kept as prisoners there and it was used as a staging area for soldiers. Worth seeing if you have the time.

I brought my 7 year old son whom is a history addict. We had a wonderful time exploring the fort. It is truly amazing what still stands after 200 years and countless hurricanes. We were able to walk the grounds exploring with free range. One can really visualize the importance or this waterfront fort.
Bathrooms were clean and picnic tables...


More  



I found this to be a great stop for some History and good views of Lake Poncentrain. It was really nice to show our young kids what it was like back in the Spanish American War.

title: Lower Garden District, New Orleans
review_list:
The historic side of New Orleans, Wonderful old homes, nice to see via carriage ride. Lots of famous people live/ed there.

A continuation of the Garden District. Area is just as charming with beautiful houses, great tree cover and places to stop and eat. The best way to see it close up is to walk around. You can take the streetcar to save time, but you should get off to explore than get back on. A great place to see.

The lower garden district is a great place to grab a bite to eat. It is also a nice neighborhood to walk around.

We took the St. Charles streetcar here ($1.25 exact change only) and enjoyed the trip through downtown. Once we reached the garden district the street opened into a stunning wide avenue lined with huge old trees and Spanish moss. We hopped off at 3rd and did a little walking tour (found on this site: http://www.gonola.com/2013/07/23/icons-of-new-orleans-architecture-garden-district-houses.html) through some of the grandest...


More  



Beautiful homes. Some are in better shape than others. Stay away from the tour leaving from the bookshop! It was terrible! Stood 45 min in the sun (got a sunburn) to hear in incorrect historical facts and a few offensive religious comments. We paid $20pp and left after 45 min of talking without reaching the first home or even the...


More  



Our hotel (Prytania Park) was in this area and we loved it. Great variety of places to see, visit and eat. If you like pizza, you definitely need to try the pizza place called Slice. It was really good.

The architecture here is amazing. Take your time and see it all! Lots of homes, stores, and restaurants to see.

It was worth taking a walk through the area. Some of it looks a little run down but beautiful homes.

A lot of crime but lovely I don't spend a lot of time there but it is a pretty area. Just a little scary for me.

I was expecting a lot more, these homes could look beautiful if the owners would just take care of them.

title: James H. Cohen and Sons, New Orleans
review_list:
We have been dealing with the brothers at Cohens for at least 20 years. We never fail to stop in their store when we are in the area. Most of our sales have been over the telephone and we have never sent anything back. What they say is what you get.

We were walking down Royal Street and saw the sign. We had to go in, and we weren't disappointed. They have an amazing collection of antique weapons, many from the early 1800's and a number from the Civil War area. They have currency from the Confederate states during the Civil War, and a large selection of coins as well. If...


More  



Just walking down royal window shopping, we decided to see what was in this shoppe. Very interesting, however, the staff did not pay attention to anyone that did not intend to buy. Disappointing considering word of mouth is the best advertisement. Teenagers even enjoyed looking at the history of the products.

If you are into firearms or rare coins or other things similiar this is the place to stop by and check out. Incredible collection

Like a museum. There are many antique weapons, money & coins. It is a bit pricey. This is a Collectors paradise.

It had been a number of years since I was last in NOLA, but was pleased to see James H. Cohen and Sons was still on Royal and still stuffed to the gills with great items. Antique guns, swords, currency, maps and other great items. A very knowledgable staff. Highly recommend.

This is one of the most enjoyable stores in the French Quarter on royal street. I am a coin collector, so browse the coins, but also enjoy looking at the wonderful gun collection from years past. While they cater to the french quarter crowds, they still advertise in the numismatic weekly publications. The only downside is that I wish more...


More  



I just love this store. They have antique weapons, coins, campaign buttons, and estate jewelry. I have also bought miniature lead "soldiers" like Gen'l Custer (hubby is a relative) and newly made gold and gemstone jewelry. This place is great for just browsing too as they have old "Dixie" notes and other historical items. They also guarantee to purchase back...


More  



We were amazed at the number of rare and unusual items at this store. We found the staff to be both knowledgable and courteous. We highly recommend visiting them even if you just want to browse their unique inventory of items.

For nearly half a century, I've stopped into James H. Cohen & Sons on Royal Street on every visit to New Orleans. If you're fascinated by historic items, there's something that will amaze you in their collection. And unlike a museum, it's all for sale. I remember buying Roman coins for my sons, and spent civil war slugs for my...


More

I traveled from Houston to New Orleans to attend a concert of my favorite musical artist at this theater. I splurged on front row tickets because I wanted everything to be perfect. The theater probably looked very futuristic when it was built, but now it jut looks dated. It's very much a building of it's time.

Went to see this fabulous comedian and heard about every other word. We have been before and sat both times in the balcony. This time we couldn't hear at all. Between his rough low voice and the poor acoustics we missed most of the show. I will never go back there

Was going to buy Broadway season tickets but I seen two shows here in two different sections and the acoustics are so bad. Also, the line for the ladies room were way too long. They need to add more bathrooms and get a new sound system throughout the entire theater for me to come here again.

One tip, Ladies - if you have just arrived and a restroom is of interest, the ones to the far left on the first floor have more stalls, so the line (always) goes quickly. There are restrooms on the other levels, so for those who are not familiar with that, it might be a better shot at the beginning. They...

Saw "Wicked" with my wife in May 2013. The Theater is small and shabby by any decent standards. The acoustics were so poor that only solo singers could be understood, any chorus singing was unintelligible. review_list:
I come to New Orleans often and I come here every time. I love this small cemetery. The room full of notes and replicas of the body parts needed healing is sad really. Who knew that one day I would leave something for someone here. I've also met one of the guardians of this place during one of the most...

While the larger cemeteries in New Orleans are certainly interesting and beautiful, this smaller site is easily accessible and charming in a very different way. The highlight is the small chapel and its collection of ex votos: polio braces, glass eyes, dental plates, handwritten notes and other meaningful objects left by the faithful. Some may find this display a bit...


More  



Visited this place the day before Halloween. It is off the wall and absurd! Quite macabre in it's presentation. Dedicated to St. Roch, patron saint of healing against the plague and in this case during the Louisiana yellow fever epidemic. Located off the beaten path in a quiet little area about 10 minutes outside of the French Quarter, yet close...


More  



Very well kept, despite recent vandalism. The Chapel and room full of "gigts" and notes to Saint Roch is heartwrenching and a little creepy. The Station of the Cross were interesting as well as all of the individual graves.
Great for photographer.

We went to this cemetery on a cool, rainy day. We took the Riverfront trolley from near the convention center to the French Market stop to shorten our hike, but it was still a decent walk, probably another 20 minutes from the French Market. If you walk, just be aware that the neighborhood is very different from the French Quarter....

I have lived in NOLA for 30 years and this is my favorite cemetary---many tombs, stations of the cross, and two chapels. I have never had any trouble in this neighborhood but one must be alert to the surroundings.

This was the cemetery we stopped out while on our city tour. It isn't well known like some of the other cemeteries, but it was still amazing to see! The above ground tombs/cemetery was something I was very much looking forward to see while in New Orleans.

If you like strolling through scenic interesting cemeteries, add this to your list. A great way to spend a few hours relaxing!

This is a small cemetary with a great history. A quick view of New Orleans cemetaries. The older crypts are particularly interesting.

This is a wonderful cematary - I have visited many times. It is a located eleven blocks from Esplanade Avenue, which divides the French Quarter and the Faubourg Marigny.
The grounds and chapel are open every day from 7am - 3pm.
St Roch - has a collection of interesting curios left by supplicants.

I love theater shows of all kind and this place is a comfy little New Orleans gem! My review is a little late, but I came here in August 2014 to see "Under The Boardwalk" with my two sisters. Saul play here on Saturday evening call dinner with friends! It was quite enjoyable and done very professionally. The four member cast were all quite talented!!

We saw Peter and the Starcatcher during our trip to NOLA. It was so well done and added the local flavor the city to our visit. The local patrons were very friendly and welcoming.

We had a lot of fun.
A must see.

Wow what a gem! The show was not only lively, upbeat, and engaging but the venue was classy and very "New Orleans". All ages were represented and look to have so much fun. I took my aunt and 18 year old niece and we all had so much fun.

My daughters and I saw "Hair" at this theater. The musical was great. Good little theater. Tried to get reservations at Tableau for dinner but that was impossible. The restaurant is connected to the theater. In a good location. Would go back.

title: Algiers Levee, New Orleans
review_list:
The Algiers levee offers superb views across the Mississippi to New Orleans' downtown skyline as well as of St Louis Cathedral. It is popular with joggers, bike-riders and dog-walkers and goes on for miles in both directions, though the views get less scenic as you get further away from the ferry terminal. If you have a bit of time it...


More  



Have a nice view of the skyline of NOLA, Road is in a very good condition and the lightning in the evening is great (LED-light that is turned brighter when motion is detected). A lot of people that are running from the old NAVI, and great place to use your bicycle.
Not so special to drive a large distance to...


More  



Walk, bike, or run. This is the place. Closest bathroom is at Dry Dock Café.
Stop and chat with passers by.

After you get off of the ferry, walk to the right and you will find yourself on the levee. It is a long, concrete promenade, good for walking, running, biking. There are benches where you can sit and look over at the skyline of the city.

Topped by a clean, well-lit, trail with ample seating that attracts locals and visitors who want respite from French Quarter excess and discover what other authentic New Orleans neighborhoods must once have been like. There is a jazz trail with a Louis Armstrong statue and some boat supply yards plus the usually busy river and downtown New Orleans just opposite....


More  



I love New Orleans but wish to experience it in small doses. That is why we are looking for a home on the West Bank only a $1 senior rate ferry boat ride form the excitement of the French Quarter. Whenever we visit we spend some quiet time walking the levy and looking at NOLA from this side of the...


More  



Great place to live!
Algiers is a break from the le bon temps roule attitude. Good food & drinks. Didn't flood during Katrina, has become a hub for the movie industry.

a lovely stroll on the West Bank. take a minute on the weekend, and pack a lunch . You can usually listen to terrific music at the Old Point Bar. If not grab a bite to eat at the dry dock cafe

This are is amazing to see. You see the city and lights and just the beauty of the whole place. For the 4th of July they have an awesome concert with local NOLA entertainment.

After some beer at the Old Point Inn, we decide to climb the imposing levee across the street. Why? Because it was there. No other reason. Nice view of New Orleans and the Mississippi River. You can follow it back to the ferry at Algiers Point. As from an earlier review, it is a dog walkers paradise. Did not notice...

title: Arcadian Books, New Orleans
review_list:
This small space is literally a jumble of books. I went in a few feet and realized how disorganized and crowded the space is. I love books but not that much.

My son finished rereading Harry Potter and needed another book to read during vacation. He certainly didn't lack for choice here. This is a real find--actually it reminded me of something out of Harry Potter--with books stacked high up into the air at impossible angles. It was a real treasure trove for book lovers. The stacks and stacks of old, fascinating, odd, and ecclectic books arranged in intriguingly precarious towers make ths small store feel like it belongs in Diagon Alley.
The proprietor, Russell, is friendly and welcoming. He goes out of his way to make visiting readers feel at home. If you love books and you're in the French Quarter, you have to...

Definitely check this place out if you're a bibliophile. Especially if you want some foreign language books, old books, or beautiful leatherbound copies of old favorites. Russell is so friendly and knowledgeable. He knows every stack and book in the place. I will definitely return if I'm ever back in NOLA.

This used books library is charming. There is a LOT of books for a small space. Claustrophobiac be aware! We were surprised to have a conversation in french with the owner too!

This shop and its owner are a real treasure. When I lived in New O, I was looking for a long out-of-print set of historical fiction, in paperback, nevertheless: "Les Rois Maudits" and just kind of mentioned it to the owner. To my utter astonishment, I got a call a few weeks later that he had the whole set. If...

title: The New Canal Lighthouse, New Orleans
review_list:
Nice to see that they restored the old lighthouse where the canal reaches Lake Ponchartrain, damaged in Hurricane Katrina.

After destruction from Hurricane Katrina, the New Canal Lighthouse was built. If you like lighthouses, this is a great stop. The view gives you an idea of the size of Lake Pontchartrain. There were restaurants in this area. There are renovations in the area that will later provide lakeside walking and park benches.

This was a stop on a Grey Lines tour. Nice job of renovating after Katrina destroyed it. Includes a upper level display with elevator access for 2. Hard to comprehend how big this lake really is - and the bridge goes on and on. Landrey's Seafood is right next door, if you're driving and have time for lunch. The Saints...


More  



It was destroyed by hurricane Katrina and rebuilt, you don't get to go to every level but a nice view of the lake.

This lighthouse was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina and now has been rebuilt. It serves as a focal point for educating the public about the need to maintain the marshes and swamps around New Orleans to mitigate future hurricanes. Docents lead tours that are quite compelling. Definitely worth a visit. This is a stop on the Grayline "Isle of Orleans" tour.

We took the Grayline tour to the lighthouse. They give a history of the lighthouse. The old one was completely destroyed in Katrina and the new one built. I enjoyed it and it is very family friendly. Carolyn

Great view of lake and causeway. Tour of lighthouse was informative and highlighted the damage Katrina inflicted on area. Guide was very knowledgeable about lake eco system, cleaning out all the debris and making lake a safe beautiful area. The second floor balcony had an awesome view of the lake. Beautiful homes in the area and well worth a drive.

While the lighthouse itself is pretty and the history behind it is interesting, that is all there is. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable. We drove all the way from the French Quarters to see it and were a little disappointed. You can only visit the first level of the lighthouse as the rest is only for employees. You cannot...


More  



We had a wonderful tour of this pretty little lighthouse. It gave us quite a lot of information about the area and especially Lake Pontchartrain. The views are pretty. It doesn't take all that long. Worth your time. Very affordable.

Nice little rebuilt lighthouse. Interesting tour but only 30% is about the lighthouse, the rest about forces of nature and what is being done to improve the lake. Very good education and great that it is being discussed with visitors which our guide John said included many school children.

Rodrique was the mastermind behind the famous "Blue Dog" and was well known in NOLA. Unfortunately, he passed away two years ago from cancer. His original works are available as well as limited signed prints. Definitely worth seeing while you're in town!

Rodrigue Studio is home to the famous Blue Dog paintings. If anyone is to blame for the dozens of copycat ideas from individuals hoping to make millions by repainting a cat, dog, bird, fleur-des-lis, baby, red dog, or whatever, it is Rodrigue.

This is a very small exhibit in the lobby of the Fed. There is not much to it but we loved it. We learned a lot about currency. There is also an interactive exhibit where you can make your own currency. You also get a back of shredded money, which the kids loved. Take a few minutes to stop by...


More  



We stopped by on our last day in town. Small musem but very informative. There is a station where you make your own money and they email it to you. It was a lot of fun. At the end there is a computer quiz to see what you leanred.

title: Spanish Plaza, New Orleans
review_list:
Excellent river views and good place to take a break from the French Quarter hustle and bustle. Nice to have some food/drink activities available, but no public restrooms? Nearest was Harrah's Casino or the Riverwalk shopping center.

Took 2 well behaved dogs here, they had a blast. Plenty to see and do. Very people friendly. Doggy bowls at some of the restaurants.

A good place to escape from downtown, our take a breather from the casinos. It's clean and open, and sometimes has a nice breeze off the river

Great spot to relax, sip, or eat. I love to watch the kids walk on the edge, and if you're lucky, at night you might see a straggler searching for the coins...

If you have been walking around woldenberg park, the outlets,the Aquarium or the harbor the "Spanish plaza" is a nice place to sit have a bite to eat/drink in one of their casual restaurants/cafe's and enjoy the nice waterfall's in the center of the plaza...

Right by the river, plenty of space, food and drink nearby.
The Outlet Collection at Riverwalk is a few steps away.
Watch the ferry, the cruise ship, or the container ships glide by.

title: Contemporary Arts Center, New Orleans
address: 900 Camp St., At St. Joseph's, New Orleans, LA 70130
review_list:
The range of opinions on the Contemporary Arts Center in New Orleans are all valid - it all just depends on what interests you.
The CAC is located across the street from the Ogden Museum of Art, which is larger and has a more extensive collection, including a fair amount of contemporary art. If you need to pick one, you...


More  



Waste of time and money. Hardly any art inside and the art they did have was overwhelmingly typical and uninspiring. Go instead to galleries on Julia Street or across the street to the awesome Ogden. Very disappointed. No food in the "cafe" either.

Very disappointed with this museum. Looking at the four-story building, you'd think it would be full of art. Not so much. Museum is only on the bottom two floors and the work is sporadic and unimpressive. Go next door to the Ogden Museum of Southern Art. That's what you're looking for:-)

What a disappointment. Spartan exhibits with little attraction. Save your money and your time. Instead, go across the street to the Ogden Museum Much more satisfying.

For such an enormous building, I was disappointed in the volume of contemporary work on display. The major exhibit “En Mas’ Carnival and Performance Art of the Caribbean” filled an entire floor but is primarily video. Often the earphones didn’t work. One audio earphone was in Spanish. Information boards about the pieces are across from the exhibits in dimly lighted...


More  



It's true that there aren't a lot of exhibits here, but the space is unique and beautiful and the art that is there is interesting. It's worth taking a look and is right across the street from the Museum for Contemporary Southern Art which is not to be missed.

The building itself is worth a trip, very contempary and unique yet its still under renovation ( at least part of it)
Enjoyed the first floor which featured the works of Radcliffe Bailey ,second floor was also great which featured "The carnival and performance art of the Caribbean. Third floor I believe had children's art..but the room itself was amazing....

Beautiful space. Expensive for VERY VERY little on display. One small room on the 3rd floor with maybe 6 pieces in it. Another gallery filled with HIGH SCHOOL ART [I had to pay to see this?]. Another floor with the stupidist installation about Carnival in the Carribean which made no sense, and very little "art" to look at. Some kitchy...

I visited on March 11th 2015 and thoroughly enjoyed the exhibit regarding Afro-Caribbean Mardi Gras experiences. Maybe the last couple of reviewers didn't have much experience with contemporary art, or don't really enjoy contemporary art, maybe it's just not their thing? We were shocked by the absence of art. There was a handful of sculptures, a few photos hung and videos playing. I consider this art center as one of the worst rip offs in the city. title: Cole Pratt Gallery, New Orleans
review_list:
FIrst, I love strolling up and down Magazine Street. Second, I love great art. What's different about Cole Pratt is that you will see art that you don't see in other galleries. They have a really nice variety of modern, contemporary, abstract art from local/regional artists ... many of them making their debut in the New Orleans art scene. The...

I visited the Cole Pratt Gallery for an open house event. I enjoyed the variety of collections they displayed. The staff was very welcoming and could tell you anything you wanted to know about each piece. Getting a history on the artists really added to the experience. I would certainly visit again - great place!

Cole Pratt is a beautiful gallery with art that ranges from edgy to traditional. The pieces were well displayed, the information on the artists was intriguing, and the staff was extremely knowledgable and welcoming. A must visit!

Been to gallery many times. Located in uptown area in a wonderful surroundings. Love the quality local artist shown there.

Cole Pratt Gallery is a real find! The owner and the others who work there are VERY knowledgable about the art and the artists. The variety offered - which is ever changing - is interesting and pleasing to the eye. If you find yourself on Magazine Street, the Cole Pratt Gallery is a place not to be missed.

I experienced the highest level of service when I visited the gallery. Not only was the staff well informed, but they made my first art buying experience an extremely easy one. They represent a wide variety of well known and important artists, as well as providing knowledge of how my piece would best be framed. I did not feel any...


More  



A spacious, yet quaint gallery right off of New Orleans' Magazine Street. Lots of magnificent artist featured, something for everyone. Friendly and very helpful staff. Definitely going back soon and I highly recommend it!

The gallery employees always make you feel welcome and accommodate your needs. They have the best contemporary art in the south.

Cole Pratt Gallery has beautiful collection of contemporary southern art produced by a variety of talented artists from around the country. The art at Cole Pratt ranges from abstract contemporary art to southern landscapes, and photorealistic paintings. The art at Cole Pratt is appropriate for the home, while meeting the highest artistic expectations. When I visit the gallery, its staff...

This artist is amazing! We bought artwork (which we got a discount for buying more than one) and we even got to meet the artist who happened to be in the gallery at the time, and even took a picture with us and the artwork we bought!

If you are enjoying the galleries on Royal, you must make sure you stop in for something that is really hard to believe at this gallery....

For generational "painting" to a version of landscapes (and that really doesn't...

Go in!! You will stop at the windows and look in... everyone does!!! Really, take those two or three steps up and into the Gallery and talk to Phil!! You may have seen copies of his amazing artwork on the web or elsewhere, but if you're in town you should visit this gallery. Craig Tracy is undoubtedly the best body painter anywhere and this

title: House of Broel's Victorian Mansion and Doll House Museum, New Orleans
address: 2220 Saint Charles Ave, New Orleans, LA 70130
review_list:
Appointment only!!! Very cool and definitely worth a visit when you are in New Orleans. The house is beautiful, and dollhouses are custom-made, each with a different theme. We were fascinated by them.

We didn't know tour were only by appointment, but the lovely owner of the house, Mrs. Broel, let us tour despite the fact they were having a wedding that night! The house was gorgeous! The second floor is full of beautiful doll houses made by Mrs. Broel herself, and you could tell she was very passionate about them, the crown...


More  



We were well received on a rainy afternoon in the Garden District. The homeowner, herself, welcomed us into this very special mansion and gardens. She also made several recommendations of New Orleans top eateries which panned out extremely well for us. Great place for a wedding!

This was the perfect place to make my dreams of a fabulous fairytale wedding come to life. Everything was truly wonderful! My husband is from New Orleans, but I'm from New York so most of my guests had never experienced a wedding in New Orleans and they were all very impressed and said they have never enjoyed a wedding reception...


More  



I attended a dinner at the House of Broel this past weekend. The venue is as unique as you can imagine - a Victorian home filled with doll houses and event spaces. The place had quirky people on staff and hosted a fun-filled, exciting event. The food was average - nothing really wowed me. We didn't have enough to eat...


More  



First and foremost, I want to thank you for opening the House of Broël to us and for hosting such a lovely ceremony and reception for us. The level of attention that we received from you and members of your professional staff was unsurpassed. The House of Broel demonstrated in significant ways the level of care it gives to its...


More  



House of Broel is the perfect setting for any event featuring elegant decor and furnishings with wonderful food. Entering the building is like stepping back in time. The owner offered many personal stories about the house and furniture. My favorite feature is the doll house collection and amazing assortment of miniatures. Must visit when you're in the Garden District.

I enjoyed looking at all the different dollhouses but also felt a bit rushed. Next time I will tell them to give me more time to look at the doll houses specially since I paid an entrance fee. Very nice dollhouses though and the house itself was interesting!

This gorgeous interior is basically redecorated for parties and weddings. Some of the house appears to be from the late 19th century so its beautiful with a lot of old wood fixtures and artifacts.
We walked in for the $10 tour and were lucky that a family of 6 had just gotten there for the same reason. The tour guide...

Beautiful venue to have a wedding. Rich in history, just an elegant location in the Garden District. We were there attending a wedding, and it was just perfect. Owner of the mansion was there and told us a lot about the history and such of the place.

title: Mother-in-Law Lounge, New Orleans
address: 1500 N. Claiborne Ave., New Orleans, LA 70116

NOLA is a big "New Orleans Saints" town. Trumpet player and singer Kermit Ruffins, the hottest act in New Orleans today, had suspended his Sunday gigs at his Treme Mother-In-Law Lounge until the Saints season is over. When we arrived in the city on a Friday, he was out of town playing in NYC. So we could not see him...


More  



Saw Kermit at another venue the night before, where he invited everyone to his place in the Treme for BBQ and music. Nice locals, great pours, and as close to a private concert with "Kermit Ruffin and the Barbecue Swingers" as you're likely to get. If he's in town he's there every Sunday. $20.00 cover but sooooooo worth it.

We went along expecting another gig, but it was more like a jam session!
Kermit Ruffin and the Barbeque Swingers were in fine form, as you'd expect as he pulled musicians from the audience to perform - his regular singer, Brittney Chauntae, Nayo Jones and even a visiting Chinese drummer amongst others.
The space is intimate so there's the opportunity...

This place is awesome. You can feel the history the moment you step inside. Kermit was nice enough to come over and chat with us before the show. He's a really nice guy and makes you feel at home. The Mother-In Law is a very historical place and important to the New Orleans music culture. I highly recommend going here...


More  



Me and the group I was traveling with, were taken here by a tour guide (Mr. Milton Carr). Instantly upon arriving you are greeted by the huge, beautiful murals on the building The margaritas are awesome and I even briefly met Kermit(more than welcoming and pleasant) who was there at the time. Not sure how often it's open, but this is where Ernie K Doe would do his magic. Building is something to see.

review_list:
I had mixed feeling about the market. Maybe on the weekend it is more interesting and perhaps because everyone raved about it. I found many things that were not made in New Orleans, and many items of inferior quality mixed in with some real finds.

Wish there was more variety when I went. Lots of repetitive items on sale. Heard it varies depending on the day you visit. Heard weekends were best, but the surrounding area and shops made for a neat walk / window shopping experience.

We were lucky that whilst we were at the French market we noticed a Flea/Farmers market on Wednesday from 2-6pm.
To be honest it was nothing special and prices were just the same as buying them in the shops.
There were speciality foods to purchase but again prices seemed a little higher than most eating places.

There is plenty to see and do and the variety of products on offer is great. From food to clothing to drinks to trinkets to jewellery to painting there is something for everyone

We had Alligator Po-Boy which was good and tasted just like chicken. The fried Oysters were out of this world and so...

Love the sights, sounds and smells of the Market. Lovely items for sale. People were so friendly. Something for everyone.

closes at 530 and too much like a Flea Market. Little restaurant stands had ok food. Way over priced and only one stand selling fresh fruit

Never the same thing twice in the Market, but you need to walk through, especially on the weekends. All sorts of stuff you don't need, sparkles, t-shirts, food/suds... great place to pick up 'gifts' for those who didn't get to come to the Big Easy

There is much to do here. There is shopping, eating, drinking, and entertainment. I found a thin wallet that I couldn't find in my home city and for only $7.00.

We found it a fun stop to shop with teenagers. The kids got their names painted by this very talented Asian man. There were the typical market things that I consider "junk" like t-shirts, cheap face masks,...

review_list:
Great gallery with lovely spaces showing the best of established and emerging contemporary artists. recent shows we have liked were by John Alexander and lin Emery, among others. Like going to a museum, except that you can purchase the exhibits if you like them. Worth the easy walk from the street car or the WW2 museum.

Went to see work by one of our favorite artists. Ended up buying a piece by someone we were unfamiliar with. Really interesting artists. Owner is knowledgeable and friendly. Is framing our piece for free (it is small) based on his suggestion.

Very nice gallery with contempary pieces .Was featuring the artist 'David Bates" which was his "costal paintings" Also had some "Chihuly " glass pieces at the back of the gallery which well goes with out saying....

Stopped in on a recent New Orleans trip and loved the art that was on display here. Some really unique collections that are both beautiful and intriguing at the same time. Definitely worth a walk through if you're roaming around in the area!

We have four pieces in BHM, a couple in Auburn, couple in SoCaro, but there were some amazing pieces on display here and have been since late April and ending in early July 2014. Always fascinated with his story and the more you learn the more jaded one can become, but still the color, movement and texture that he and...


More  



This was closed when I approached the door, but the owner invited me in to look around. What I found was a fabulous, light, airy, well organized display of spectacular art. Highly recommend, but don't go on a Monday. :)

title: Washington Square Park, New Orleans
address: 700 Elysian Fields Ave., New Orleans, LA
review_list:
This park is a good place to recharge. Its population includes families on the play equipment, couples, picnickers, and jugglers and other street performers rehearsing and practicing. As much as I enjoy New Orleans, I really enjoy the islands of calm that I find in the neighborhoods.
Washington Square park is at the end of the Frenchman St. performance area...

Nice to walk around or sit in for an hour to watch the practicing street performers, we saw jugglers and watched a film set where they were shooting a TV programme.
I would suggest taking a picnic here in the day time or just walking around en route to Frenchmen street and the French quarter for a more authentic NOLA...

Found this little park while taking a walk on Frenchmen street. Nice enough park and would be great to hang out in. Personally, I felt uncomfortable being there...


More  



Washington Square Park was small but well-suited for its purpose - a local park with enough play equipment, enough open space and enough seats and shade. Locked at night of course.

This park was very nice place to sit and relax. It was a very good spot to stop and watch people. There was music filling the air and lots of restaurants close by.

Went here briefly yesterday to meet a friend who was working in the shops, but this is a nice place to go one street over from the French Quarter past Esplanade avenue. Will go here for sure next time to spend more time here and even have some seafood.

I live very near here and I have been to this park many times. It's a great place to walk your dog or people watch. Local acrobats practice here and on nice days you always here gentle music being played.
The oak trees act as a natural air conditioner too! During the power outage after hurricane Isaac this park was...


More  



Excellent place to take a break and relax after walking through the French Quarter and up Frenchman street. A few locals were hanging out in the park and the area seemed quite safe.

title: New Orleans Centre, New Orleans

Due to the Hurricane my Delta flight was cancelled. But, I want to thank Delta Airlines because I
have already had the full cost redeposited to my credit card. No questions asked.

We went to New Orleans for a few days before and after our cruise and we enjoyed it at least as much as the cruise!

I have visited this museum, both before and after Katrina. They suffered thirty feet of flood water during Katrina, but, have recovered and, it's better than ever. The old museum, including a number of artifacts, was destroyed by Hurricane Katrina. This new facility has recently opened. There are large areas for exhibits that tell the history of the National Guard in Louisiana. They have firearms, uniforms, battle flags, a recreated World War II barracks and more on display inside. Stop in and see how the National Guard has impacted the people of New Orleans and Louisiana. The displays are very well done and show the resiliency of the Guard.

Having been there on many visits with out of town friends, their compliments make me realize the quality of this facility.

History stared you right in the face at Jackson Barracks a
military museum and attraction rich in America's history. Modern and Old time weapons of war are displayed prouldy along the court yard and inside
the museum. History of New Orleans fighting men and women whose spirits still resonate from walls built to protect the land mark during the civil...

title: Poeyfarre Market, New Orleans
review_list:
This is definitely my favorite grocery store in town. Places like this are the reason why I love the city of New Orleans. I always make it a point to stop by when I'm in the warehouse district.

Poeyfarre is spectacular and really embodies New Orleans. You can often find the super-friendly brothers that own it working behind the counter and talking with the customers. They have great prepared food made on-site as well as a large selection of snacks, pastries, and drinks, including a good selection of wine and liquor.

We visted this store almost daily. Loved the coffee and the prepared meals. Great prices, and they sell alcohol.

Great neighborhood market with tons of great choices. One of the best iced coffees I've ever had-- mixed mine with some almond milk and simple syrup. Perfect treat to walk around with on a sunny day!

Very convenient walk from the Residence Inn. A little overpriced, but I would expect that from the area. Has a decent wine selection. I was glad to find out how close they were to my hotel. The puzzle art is amazing.

Poeyfarre is a great little market with healthy and tasty prepared meals, awesome coffee and helpful people. Their Veronica Blue salad with chicken is the best. I pick one up to take for lunch whenever I can. It's not cheap, but it's quality. You can get cheap anywhere.

Poeyfarre is my favorite place to get lunch in downtown NOLA! Amazingly friendly service, delicious sandwiches. Even better, their gourmet grocery store has things I just can't find at Rouse's. It is a pleasure to go in here and I love the fact that it is family owned. So convenient if you're in the CBD or Warehouse District. Highly recommend!

I come here for lunch at least once a week. It's great food and the owners are great. I would definitely recommend it for lunch and any last minute needs.

title: Hurricane Katrina Memorial, New Orleans
review_list:
This memorial is very tastefully done. It's beautiful and quiet. A wonderful place for reflection. I went to the 10th anniversary ceremony at this site and was kind of disappointed at all of the politicians and media that were present. I would have liked to see more local attendance.

I liked the extensive use of video media to tell the story of Hurricane Katrina, and the events leading up to it. The museum is well organised and interesting. Quite devastating. However, there was conflicting noise from the various videos that were playing at the same time.

A little hard to find but a must for tourists. It was a very sad reminder of all that was lost in hurricane Katrina and a good history lesson for the kids who don't know about or remember the tragedy.

Located directly across street from Morial Convention Center. Shows a small house in top of a tree - beautiful, low-key and poignant - also free. Strongly recommended.

I liked the displays and the testimonial video in the end. I wish it was more spead out. Some exhibits were too crowded to view.

Education about the events leading up to and following Hurricane Katrina. Unless you experienced it first hand, you really would have a hard time understanding the devastation that the people of New Orleans and the landscape endured. The Katrina Memorial, located next to St. Louis Cathedral in the square, is must see. It really helps you to understand the loss...


More  



Memorial park inside the cemetery district in New Orleans. 1100 people died during the hurricane Katrina in August 2005. In this park, you can see the unmarked tombs of the hundreds of victimes who's body were never identified.
The best way to get to the memorial is to take the Canal Streetcar Tram to the end of the line -...

If there was any artist who evokes a sense of place that is New Orleans, this guy is it. I ended up with a print for the music room (jaune flyer) in our...

Very welcoming host, the art was spectacular. It was priced out of range for the average tourist, but a real treat to the art enthusiast of the unique architecture of New Orleans and James' unique capturing of it on canvas.

I was looking for a large piece of art for the house I was building. I didn't want a print or a painting of usual NOLA scenes like swamps, boats, mossy oaks. I like those but I wanted unique. I found him one year at Jazz Festival and knew he would be the artist for my painting. Once I was...


More  



Not to buy a print (or even a poster, for the budget conscious). The use of color and texture, the obvious love for the architecture and vibe of the city, I had to have it. It was a strain on the wallet, but I'll never regret my purchase.

I was attracted to this gallery after seeing a small piece of the artist's work in an advertisement. I was blown away by the amazing use of color, perspective and texture in his paintings. The thing that most impressed me is that Mr. Michalopoulos has in him the same strange connection to the vibe of New Orleans that resides in...

Everyone should aspire to own art as amazing as this. If you do nothing else in New Orleans be sure to visit The Michalopoulos gallery. His paintings are windows into other dimensions.

title: As You Like It Silver Shop, New Orleans
review_list:
Truly the only shop in town with the best selection and the nicest most knowledgable owners. Whether making a purchase or having an item cleaned or restored you know these are honest good people.
One of the jewels of Magazine Street

We stopped by the " As You Like It Silver Shop " and what a nice surprise. You might just find what you are looking for there. Tell Tammy hello from us too!

Every time I go to New Orleans, I make a point to visit As You Like It Silver Shop. It's a feast for the eyes! And, their inventory is quite extensive. Make it part of your next visit!

I have only spoken to the owners wife over the phone but when I visit New Orleans I am so popping in to this shop! The candlesticks she helped me order (for my picky husband) are perfection. Exactly what he wanted and wrapped beautifully for Christmas. First class service and pieces.

Although this beautiful shop did not carry my pattern, one of the gentlemen there suggested I email him a picture of my pattern so he could be on the lookout for it. Great customer service and beautiful shop!

my sister, Sherry and I drove all the way from Shreveport to Natchez to see Juanita at the "As You Like It" shop. We bought "Love Disarmed." My friend took me to check out the art; he goes every time he visits New Orleans. Huge selection of art in a variety of sizes and prices. I took two pieces home with me.

I recommend this place as one...

title: New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival, New Orleans

I have been doing the festival since 2007. You get the best music of all kinds from rock, country, soul, jazz, blues and gospel. A range of all age groups. Great food and you have time to go explore the city at night it a great time.

title: N'awlins Cigar & Coffee, New Orleans
address: 635 St. Ann Street, New Orleans, LA 70130
review_list:
We enjoy smoking cigars, but to be honest, we really needed to use a bathroom and that is what brought us into this cigar shop. The owner was very nice and let us smell several cigars before choosing our favorites. She was a lot of fun and talked to us about our astrological signs and how that affected us as...


More  



The cigars were over priced for low quality smokes. The customer service was terrible. The lady cut my cigar, rank up my purchase, solicited me for a tip, (which I gave her $1) then she told me she didn't have any matches. If in New Orleans and need a cigar, try the Cigar Factory.

title: Gravier Street Social, New Orleans
review_list:
Good place but no good attention...
Such a good tables and bar, but nobody realized you had arrived.
I have to write more about this place but no good customer satisfaction, let say the music is good but nothing that Spotify could bring you.

Major bad. Bartender c 3-4 days on the job. No ingredients for drinks on the very limited menu. Couldn't compile the simplist drink. Other 'tender said- " I don't like gin". Walked out. THIS NO GUYS, GET IT TOGETHER. I'm here for Tales. From the City. This is an embarrassment.

We had a great time here. Great atmosphere for drinks. We stayed till 10 and watched the burlesque show. The show was great. The girls were beautiful and very classy. Just keep in mind these are dancers not strippers. However, this is an adult venue.

Excellent 'soho house' vibe lounge in the middle of downtown New Orleans. The only place we could find like this in the whole city. We went in for drinks after seeing their Summer on the Thames Pimms Cocktail rated on Zagat.com during the Tales of the Cocktail, we were not disappointed. Amazing drinks, super cool vibe, we'll be back!
